name: 2015 Libya Scaravilli
description:
Originaire de Catane (Sicile), le médecin italien Ignazio Scaravilli, 68 ans, a été enlevé le 6 janvier 2015 par un groupe de jihadistes lié aux islamistes radicaux de Ansar Al-Sharia, selon les médias italiens.

Libéré en juin, le sexagénaire serait à Tripoli, en attente de rentrer en Italie. Selon les médias italiens, il aurait été libéré il y a une semaine mais placé depuis au secret par les autorités libyennes. 

Chirurgien orthopédique, spécialiste de la main, Ignazio Scaravilli était parti avant Noël pour la Libye en compagnie de collègues siciliens afin d'apporter son aide à un hôpital.

name: 2014 Nigeria-Cameroon Nitsch Eberhard Robert Kidnapping
description: Nitsch Eberhard Robert, a German citizen, was kidnapped in July 2014 in Nigeria, apparently by Boko Haram. On January 21, 2015, Cameroon’s President Paul Biya announced that Robert had been rescued by special forces – his country’s and others, not specified.

name: 2013 Syria Daniel Rye Ottosen
description:
Daniel Rye Ottosen, a Danish freelance photographer, was captured in Syria on 17 May last year after travelling to the country to "document the conflict and the living conditions of civilians, especially children," his family said in a statement.

He has been freed after being held hostage in Syria for 13 months.

Sources close to the situation told news agency Ritzau that the Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant (ISIL) was behind the kidnapping and that a ransom had been paid for Ottosen's release.

The family said the 25-year-old was "under the circumstances (feeling) well and is now about to be reunited with his family."

"Daniel's case has long been known by the Danish press, but in the interest of Daniel's security everyone has refrained from covering the story," it said.

A former elite gymnast, his family had appealed to gymnastics groups to contribute to the ransom payment, Danish media reported

name: 2014 Syria UK journalists
description:

Two British journalists, photographer Jack Hill and reporter Anthony Lloyd, both working for The Times, were kidnapped in Syria early on the morning of May 7, 2014 while attempted to reach Turkey. They were less than 20 kilometers from the border.

As he was pushed into the trunk of a car with his guide, Hill noted that his captors included men whom the journalists had entrusted with their safe conduct to the border.

The two reporters were freed on May 13,apparently under the orders of a commander of the Islamic Front, an anti-Al Qaeda rebel group. They crossed the border into Turkey after having spent time in a Syrian hospital. Lloyd had been shot twice in the leg while being held hostage, and Hill was recovering from a severe beating administered after he attempted to escape.

name: 2014 Nigeria Dutch hostages
description:
Three Dutch nationals, two men and woman, working on a magazine story about Nigeria, and two Nigerians accompanying, them were abducted in the Niger Delta on May 4, 2014 when they arrived at a hospital built by American oil company Chevron. They were freed on May 10.

According to environmental activist Sunny Ofehe, who was present when the kidnapping took place but who was freed shortly thereafter, the abduction was motivated by money. He said the kidnappers told him that they didn’t have any work, that the foreign oil companies did not hire local workers, and that they were “forced to do it”.

A Nigerian government official said at the time of their release that he had ‘no information’ about a ransom.

name: 2014 Yemen Mike Harvey
description:
Briton Mike Harvey, an instructor, was kidnapped in Yemen on February 3, 2014 while returning from a language school where he taught. He was released on July 26 the same year following negotiations led by the Sanaa government, according to British and Yemeni authorities. 

Previously, however, a Yemeni official has claimed that Harvey had been freed by security forces in collaboration with tribal forces in the region of Al-Jouf, northeast of Sanaa.

name: 2014 Libya Italian workers
description:
Two Italian construction workers kidnapped in Libya on January 17 have been released and returned to Italy thanks to joint work by the Italian government and the Libyan army and secret services, officials said.

Italy's ambassador to Libya, Giuseppe Buccino, told AFP that they were released "thanks to the co-operation between Italy and the Libyan army and secret services".

The two were in Libya working on a road building project in the city of Derna for the contractor General World and had only been in Libya for a few months.

They were seized from their van by armed men outside Derna in eastern Libya, reports said.

name: 2013 Syria Swedish journalists
description:
Freelance Swedish photographer Niclas Hammarström, working for the Kontinent photo agency, and journalist Magnus Falkehed, working for the daily Dagens Nyheter, were taken hostage on November 14, 2013 in western Syria by an unidentified rebel group. They were released in early January 2014.

The conditions surrounding their capture and release remain murky. They were taken hostage while making their way toward the Lebanese border after having slipped into Syria to do reporting. Hammarström was shot in the leg while attempting to escape his captors, and said after his release that he and Nyheter had been beaten, barely fed and otherwise poorly treated during their detention.

name: 2003 Fred Nerac Kidnapping
description:
French national Fred Nérac, 43, working as a cameraman for British TV station ITN, disappeared near Basra in southern Iraq on March 22, 2013, two days after the start of the coalition offensive. 

The French foreign ministry later concluded that Nérac likely died during the fighting. The Lebanese interpreter that was traveling in the same car as Nerac, along with British journalist Terry Lloyd, in another vehicle, were killed on the same day. A Belgian cameraman, Daniel Demoustier, was injured.

The Nerac family, however, remained unconvinced by the French government’s account of events, noting in particular witness accounts suggesting that the French cameraman had been taken by Iraqis and put into the back of a pick-up truck.

name: 2013 Syria Polish Journalist
description:
Polish 34-year-old photojournalist Marcin Suder, who worked for the Corbis agency and other outlets, was abducted by masked gunmen on July 24 during a raid on a media centre in Saraqeb in the northwestern province of Idlib, Syria.

The freelancer is safely back home after escaping his captors, Poland's foreign ministry said.

Polish officials did not reveal how Marcin Suder was able to flee or give details of his time in captivity, saying only that he has been back in Poland for "some days".

"He was very lucky, he managed to escape," foreign ministry spokesman Marcin Wojciechowski told AFP. 

He added: "He's here since some days, surrounded by his family. He is in good health."

No reason was given for his kidnapping and no one publicly claimed responsibility for the abduction.

"Polish consular services in the region helped the photographer return home," Wojciechowski told reporters.

Suder's mother said her son was in shock but otherwise mentally fine.

"Physically, he's thin and, let's say, some marks of something remain on his body. But he really doesn't look that bad," Krystyna Jarosz told Poland's commercial RMF FM radio.

Without explaining the marks, she said he was held in a dark basement, without food at first: "Later he got a bit of food. It wasn't a spa, I'll put it that way."

name: 2013 Syria German Aid workers
description:
German engineer Ziad Nouri was kidnapped with two other members of the group on May 15 in the Syrian village of Harem, near the Turkish border where the organisation was renovating a nursery.

The aid worker held for almost four months has escaped his kidnappers in Syria, just like his two colleagues who managed to flee in July, their aid group announced.

Engineer Ziad Nouri "is free" and managed to cross the Syrian border into Turkey on Tuesday, the Gruenhelme non-governmental organisation said in a statement.

"He freed himself," it said.

His two colleagues Simon Sauer and Bernd Blechschmidt escaped on July 3, the NGO said. The German foreign ministry confirmed their release at the time.

Gruenhelme (Green Helmets) has been in northern Syria for several months to help the reconstruction of local infrastructures and to provide healthcare.

name: 2013 Pakistan Czech students
description:
Humpalova and Chrastecka, both psychology students, were kidnapped on March 13, 2013, in the southwestern Baluchistan province while being escorted by a tribal policeman after crossing into Pakistan from Iran on holiday.

The two young Czech women have been freed and have returned home, Prime Minister Bohuslav Sobotka said.

He added that the two 26-year-old women were freed with the help of the Turkish Muslim humanitarian organisation IHH.

Izzet Sahin, the IHH official leading the negotiations with the kidnappers, told the agency the families of the victims had contacted the Turkish charity as a last resort after exhausting all other means to save the pair.

In a video released shortly after the kidnapping, the two young Czechs pleaded for the release of Pakistani neuroscientist Aafia Siddiqui, jailed in 2010 in the United States on charges of terrorist links.

In another video shot in August 2013 and released two months later, Humpalova called on the Czech government to exert pressure on Islamabad to return her to her homeland "as soon as possible".

Speaking to Anadolu, Humpalova said: "It was very hard. For the first time in our lives we saw weapons and armed men."

"We still do not know why were taken. There were weapons fired and bombs going off. But we got used to it in time."

She said the worst part of their two-year ordeal was being apart from their families.

name: 2013 Colombia Spanish tourists
description:
Maria Concepcion Marlaska Sedano, 43, and Angel Fernandez Sanchez, 49, tourists from Spain, were abducted on May 17, in the north Colombian province of Guajira by a group of armed men.  They were rescued a month later by a special hostage unit of the national police on June 14.

In a press conference in Madrid after their release, Sanchez described the experience as ‘traumatizing’. He said that he and Sedano, after being kidnapped, were transported for two hours in a car before their abductors told them to get out and to kneel by the roadside. “At that moment, we embraced each other in tears and said a prayer together out loud. We said goodbye because we were sure – 100% sure – that they were going to kill us.”

The young travelers vowed to marry if they lived through the ordeal, but now needed to consult with their families and each other, he added.

name: 2013 Egypt Ingvil Selvik Ask
description:
An Israeli Arab Amir Omar Hassan, and 31-year-old Norwegian Ingvild Selvik Ask, who had asked to share his taxi, were abducted on March 22, 2013 as they travelled from the Red Sea resort of Taba, on the border with Israel, to the coastal town of Dahab further south.

"They set a trap for us with two jeeps that stopped us," Hassan told reporters on his arrival at Ben Gurion airport.

"About 10 armed men got out and threw us in the back of the jeeps," he said in remarks broadcast by Israeli radio stations. "They said shut up, you're going to die now".

The two tourists were set free early on March 26, thanks to the efforts of Bedouin tribesmen, said an Egyptian security official cited by state news agency MENA.

name: 2012 Norway Dadaab Camp
description:
Four foreign aid workers (Steven Dennis, 37, Astrid Sehl, 33, Glenn Costes, 40 and Sadazai, 38), kidnapped in Kenya's Dadaab refugee camp appeared to be otherwise in good health after arriving from the southern Somali border town of Dhobley, where they been freed earlier on Monday.

"They were released by a joint force of Somali and Kenyan forces, during which one of the kidnappers was killed," Kenyan army spokesman Cyrus Oguna told AFP. Three others were arrested.

name: 2013 Yemen Sylvia Abrahat
description:
Swiss national Sylvia Abrahat, 36, was abducted on March 14, 2012 fromher house in Hodeidah, western Yemen, by armed men and taken to Chabwa, anAl-Qaeda stronghold in the southeast. She was in Yemen working in a languageinstitute.


Her kidnappers demanded the release of fellow tribesmen in exchange for herfreedom, the Yemeni interior ministry said at the time. In avideo put online in May 2012, she declared that she was in handsof Al-Qaeda fighters. In a subsequent video, she appealed for helpfrom the Swiss government. She was released on February 27, 2013.

name: 2012 Yemen Benjamin Malbrancke
description:
Benjamin Malbrancke, a French staffer with the Red Cross, was abducted by gunmen on April 21 while on his way to the airport in the northern port city of Hudaida. He had been held in a mountainous region between the provinces of Shabwa and Abyan across the south, and released through tribal mediation.

Two drivers captured at the same time were freed shortly afterwards.

On June 20, Yemeni Red Cross worker Hussein Saleh was killed in air strikes that left 30 Al-Qaeda suspects dead in Mahfad.

A relative said he was killed as he travelled in the south along with the head of the ICRC for the southern port city of Aden on a mission to help negotiate the release of Malbrancke.

The ICRC had said Saleh died in unclear circumstances while on a humanitarian mission.

name: 2013 Mali execution
description:
Ghislaine Dupont and the technician Claud Verlon were reporter for Radio France Internationale (RFI). They were doing a report in Kidal, Mali, to cover the difficult situation in the North of the country. 

On 3rd November, 2013 they are arrested by unidentified assailants that announced their execution several hours later. 

According to the French government, the assailants were linked to AQIM islamists.

name: 2011 Abidjan kidnapping
description:
Stéphane Frantz di Rippel was a business man for the Accor hotel company. He was the director of the Abidjan Novotel which was very used by journalists during the post-electoral crisis of 2010-2011.  

On April 4th, 2011 Stéphane Frantz di Rippel had been captured by pro-Gbagbo militia. When the militia entered the hostel, they found him and had been asked to know where journalists hid. He said they were no journalist in his hotel — but a dozen were hidden on a floor above. 

They eventually captured and tortured him. His death was announced on June 2, 2011 but his body was never found.

name: 2005 Iraq Ulf Hjertström
description:
Ulf Hjertström, 63, a Swedish businessman, was kidnapped on March 25, 2005 in Iraq. He had been living in Iraq for 14 years and worked as an oil trader. After his release on May 29, he said that  he had witnessed the execution of several people in his holding cell. "We were ordered to take our masks off and watch," Hjertstrom said. He added that the ability to pay ransom made the difference between life and death for those detained, those he brother later denied that any ransom was paid for Hjertstrom's release.

Among those detailed with him was Australian businessman Douglas Wood, who was also released.

name: 2001 Colombia Lothar Hintze kidnapping
description:
A German citizen, Lothar Hintze, was captured on 16 March, 2001 next from Bogotá, by the FARCs, Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia. After five years of captivity, he was finally freed on 4 April 2006.

He was working in Bogota were he owned an hotel called the "Seehotel Nautico". According to the German newspaper Frankfurter Allgemeine, a ransom was paid several times during his detention. But he was not liberated.

name: 2005 Iraq Susanne Osthoff
description:
Susanne Kristina Osthoff was born on March 7, 1962 in Munich. She is a German archaeologist who had worked in Iraq since 1991. 

In summer 2005, the threats were judged to be serious and the German embassy asked Osthoff to leave the country. She refused and decided to stay and continue her work. 

On November 25, Osthoff and her driver are going to Arbil from Baghdad. But they vanished. Shortly after, a DVD containing a video clip was given to the ARD office in Baghdad. In the video, the two captives are shown surrounded by masked, armed men who read a statement demanding that the German government immediately cease all cooperation with the Iraqi government. 

She was freed by her captors on December 18, 2005. Their captors are presumably an islamist group around the Jordanian native Al-Zarqaoui. 

Although German government never confirmed it, Susanne Osthoff had been freed for a $3-million ransom, paid by Berlin, according to different sources.

name: 2014 Libya Salviato
description: On March 2014 the 22th, Gianluca Salviato, 48, engineer working in Tobrouk for the italian building trade Enrico Ravanelli is kidnapped by an armed Milice. These Milice could belong to a coalition of islamist Milices proliferating in the South of Libya since the fall of Kadhafi in 2011. After six months of captivity, Salviato is released.

name: 2002 Heiner Hansen kidnapping
description:
German Heiner Hansen, 64, owner of a foreign trade consultancy and a port operations firm, was kidnapped near Buenaventura port in December 2002 by a group of unidentified armed assailants while driving to the airport to catch a flight to Bogota. He was released six months later.

Hansen had been living in Colombia for several years and frequently traveled between Bogota and Buenaventura.  His kidnapping was was attributed to the FARC (Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia). 

Also abducted was Hansen's 35-year-old Colombian general manager, Julio Valencia.

name: 2014 Yemen Isabelle Prime
description:
Isabelle Prime is a 30-year-old women who vanished on 24 February 2014 by a group that has not claimed this rapt.

She was a consultant for an American company. 

She had been captured with her Yemenite translator, Chérine Makkaoui. The latter had been released on 10th March 2014, in Aden (Yemen).

name: 2011 Somalia Evelyne Colombo
description: Evelyne Colombo and her husband Christian Colombo are attacked by Somalian pirates in the Gulf of Aden on September 8, 2011. They were aboard a sailboat. They had left France in 2008 to go to Thailand to catamaran. During the attack, Christian Colombo, a retired man of the French navy, is killed while he tries to defend his wife and his boat. Evelyne Colombo is taken by the pirates who try to return in Somalia. Alerted by calls for help, the boats of the European strength Atalante look for the kidnappers and their hostage. A French helicopter locates them and a Spanish military ship intercepts them on September 10, 2011. Evelyne Colombo is got back and seven pirates are captured. Christian Colombo's body, thrown to the sea, was not found.

name: 2004 Iraq Henrik Frandsen
description: Danish subcontractor Henrik Frandsen, 35, in Iraq to work on sewage infrastructure, was abducted while driving on a highway in the town of Tadji near Baghdad on April 11, 2004.  His body was found 10 days later. It is thought that he might have been the victim of a highway robbery.

name: 2013 Cameroon Georges Vandenbeush
description: Father Georges Vandenbeush is a catholic priest of Nanterre. He leaves in the North of Cameroon in 2011 within the framework of an exchange between dioceses. He is kidnapped on November 13, 2013 in the North of Cameroon and is held captive in the North of Nigeria by the Islamic group Boko-Haram. He is freed December 31, 2013 and returns in France. The Cameroonian president Paul Biya would have played a large part in Georges Vandenbeush's liberation.

name: 2009 Mauritania Italian Couple
description:
December 18th,2009, retired man Sergio Cicala and his wife Philomène Kaboure, of origin Burkinabe, were kidnapped by gunmen in the South of Mauritania, near the border with Mali. They circulated aboard amini-van towards Burkina Faso to visit the son of madam Kaboure. Theywere kidnapped by gunmen who passed on them in the hands of Al-Qaedain the Islamic Maghreb. They were transferred in Mali. 


On April 16th, 2010, the couple was freed released near Gao, in Mali, having been held in the desert. Philomène Kaboure explained that they were never mistreated but that the living conditions were very difficult.

name: 2009 Philippines Eugenio Vagni
description:
On January 15th, 2009, a person in charge of Italian Red Cross named Eugenio Vagni was kidnapped in the Philippines with two of his colleagues while they inspected a construction site of purification of a prison to Jolo. 


Three men were retained captives by the rebels of the group Abou Sayyaf. Two other hostages were released in April. 
On July 11th, 2009, Eugenio Vagni was released after the Philippine government agreed to free two women of the leader of the group Abou Sayyaf.

name: 2014 Jeppe Nybroe kidnapping
description:
Jeppe Nybroe, a Danish freelance journalist was taken hostage on February 7, 2014. He was released on March 7, 2014. 

According to the Danish newspaper Jyllands-Posten, Jeppe Nybroe was abducted on February 7 from the Lebanese border town of Arsal with a Lebanese-Palestinian journalist, Rami Aysha, and then transferred to Syria. Sources from Arsal denied the kidnapping took place inside the town and said that the journalists were taken after they crossed the border to the Yabroud region in Syria.

The two journalists were inquiring on kidnappings in the area.

name: 2011 Palestine Gaza
description:
The morning of April 14th, 2011, the Italian pacifist activist of the pro-Palestinian organization International Solidarity Movement Vittorio Arrigoni was removed by a group salafi-jihadist. 

VittorioArrigoni lived in the Gaza Strip since August, 2008. The salafisthreatened to kill Vittorio Arrigoni if their companions held by theHamas, in particular the sheik Hesham al Saeedni, was not released. 

On April 15th, 2011, Vittorio Arrigoni wasexecuted. His body was discovered in a district of the northwest of the city of Gaza.

name: 2009 Somalia Tanit
description: Florent Lemaçon, a Breton skipper, had left with his wife Chloé, his son Colin and two other team members (Pierre Dorian and Steven Ménoret) from the city of Vannes (France) in 2008 to go to Zanzibar aboard the sailboat Tanit. They had to establish in Zanzibar a humanitarian project. The sailboat is attacked by Somalian pirates on April 4, 2009. They approach the boat of the Somalian coast. They are followed by French warships. After fruitless negotiations, the French commando squads launch an attack on April 10, 2009. Two pirates are killed. Florent Lemaçon is taken for a pirate and is killed by a French commando squad. Other hostages are freed and three pirates are captured. Judged in France, three Somalian pirates were 9-year-old condemned persons of prison in April, 2013 by the criminal court of Rennes. Chloé Lemaçon, Florent's wife, accused the French government of having led a risky attack which cost the life of her husband.

name: 2013 Nigeria construction company
description:
Seven persons working for the Setrapo construction company, were kidnapped on February 16, 2013. They were taken from the construction company's camp at Jama'are, a town about 200 kilometres north of Bauchi by the islamic group, Ansaru. 

Among the captives, were four Lebanese, a Briton, Brendan Vaughan, an Italian Silvano Trevisan and a Greek. 

They were killed a few weeks later on March 10, 2013. The terrorists said they killed the "seven Christian foreigners" because they believed British jets were being readied for a rescue mission, a claim the Ministry of Defence has denied.

name: 2011 Somalia Danish aid workers
description:
The Dane Poul Thisted, 60, was taken hostage in Somalia on October 25, 2011, with another aid worker, the American, Jessica Buchanan. They were seized by gunmen in the semi-autonomous Galmudug region.

They were released on January 24, 2012, by US elite commandos. Nine kidnappers died in a firefight during the raid by elite Navy SEALS.

They were employed by the Danish Refugee Council Demining Group helping to de-mine Somalia.

name: 2013 Syria Rai TV
description:
On April 4th, 2013, four Italian journalists of a team of Rai TV weretaken hostage in the northwest of Syria by an Islamist armed group.Amedeo Ricucci was a special correspondent of the public channel Rai,Elio Colavolpe reporter and photographer, Andrea Vignali author ofdocumentaries and Susan Dabbous journalist freelance of Syrianorigin. They were all in Syria to film a documentary. 

During their detention of eight days, the hostages were moved in diverse prisons by their kidnappers. 

April 13th, 2013, four journalists were released. They said in the Italian media not to have been mistreated.

name: 2014 Syria Italian Aid Workers
description:
On July 31st, 2014, Vanessa Marzullo and Greta Ramelli, two young italian aid workers, disappeared near Aleppo, in the North of Syria,where they had arrived three days earlier from Turkey. Both women had established an association of mutual aid baptized "Horryaty",specialized in water and healthcare. They were kidnapped by members of Jabhat Al-Nusra, the al-Qaeda affiliate group inSyria. 

In December, 2014, they appeared in a video dressed in black and combed by a scarf.

Vanessa Marzullo and Greta Ramelli were released on January 15th, 2015. According to the Arabic media, a 12 million euro ransom has been paid. But Italy denies paying 12 million euro ransom for aidworkers.

name: 2013 Syria Jonathan Alpeyrie
description: Jonathan Alpeyrie is kidnapped in the North of Damascus by an Islamist group of rebels opposedto the regime of Bachar el-Assad. He was in Syria to realize a report on the bombardment of the town of Yabroud by the Syrian regime. He would have been betrayed by his translator. His gaolers suspect him of being an American spy. He is changed several times places before being retained captive in a house next to the Lebanese border. This house is the headquarters of his kidnappers and is the target of numerous bombardments. On July 20th he is given to the agents of a rich businessman, close to the Syrian government, which would have paid a $450 000 ransom to free him. Jonathan Alpeyrie is taken in Damascus and then in Beirut. There, he escapes his new guards and takes refuge with the embassy of France. He returns in France on July 24th, 2013.

name: 2012 Pakistan Multan
description:
On January 12th, 2012, Giovanni Lo Porto and his German colleague Bernd Muehlenbeck, both humanitarian workers, were kidnapped in thecity of Multan, in Pakistan, by members of Al-Quaida. Giovanni LoPorto was in Pakistan for three days at the time of his kidnapping.With his colleague Bernd Muehlenbeck, they worked for a German NGO. Bernd Muehlenbeck was later freed inside Afghanistan.

On January 15th, 2015, Lo Porto was killed in a U.S. drone strike on a Al-Qaeda facility in the Afghanistan-Pakistan border region. The operation also killed American aid worker Warren Weinstein. The American government thought that there was no civilian on the site.

name: 2013 Syria French journalists
description: Didier François and Edouard Elias were kidnapped on June 6th, 2013 near the city of Aleppo, in Syria. Pierre Torres and Nicolas Hénin were deprived on June 22nd, 2013 of Raqqa, in Syria also. The kidnapping of Pierre Torres and Nicolas Hénin was revealed by the French government only on October 9th, 2013. Four French journalists were detained by the group ISIS during 10 months in Syria, sometimes next to frontlines. The hostages were retained in cellars, and some of their gaolers spoke French. Nicolas Hénin tried to escape, but was caught up by his gaolers. The captivity continues. The 18th April, 2014, they are released in borders Turkish and got back by Turkish frontier officers. They return in France on April 20th, 2014. In September, 2014, Nicolas Hénin reveals that the hostages were tortured and that one of their gaolers was Mehdi Nemmouche, the author of the slaughter of the Jewish museum of Brussels. Didier François condemned these revelations, by considering that they could put in danger the life of the hostages still held by ISIS. According to the German newspaper Focus, France would have paid 18 millions dollars of ransom. French government denied that.

name: 2013 Syria Mario Belluomo
description: On December 12th, 2012, two Russian citizens and the Italian national Mario Belluomo were kidnapped by Syrian extremists on the road between Homs and Tartous, in the West of Syria. Three men worked in a private Syrian foundry, Hmisho and Co, situated near Homs. On February 3rd, they were released in exchange for the liberation of three Syrian insurgents who were in the hands of the army. Three men were then healthy.

name: 2013 Afghanistan Charles Ballard
description: Charles Ballard was the financial director of the NGO Acted, in Afghanistan. On January 7th, 2013, it is kidnapped by armed men in the city of Kabul while he went to the work. He is then detained struck and detained in toilet during several months. He is freed on April 7th, 2013. His detention was maintained secret and no ransom would have been paid.

name: 2013 Afghanistan Pierre Borghi
description: Pierre Borghi is a photographer. In 2011 and 2012, he had already come in Afghanistan to work in the French NGO Solidarities International. He comes back in Afghanistan from a short absence to realize a photographic work. He is kidnapped in Kabul on November 27th, 2012 by Talibans and held captive. The Talibans ask for a ransom for freed Pierre Borghi. But the negotiations do not move forward and they threaten to execute the hostage. Pierre Borghi succeeds in escaping on April 7th, 2013 and to reach the commissionership of the city of Maydan Shar. He is repatriated towards Kabul then towards France. He then wrote a book on his captivity.

name: 2005 Cambodia Siem Reap
description:
On June 16th, 2005, a group of 6 cambodian bandits took hostage 29 pupils ofage between two and six years in an international school of Siem Reap, in a northwest of the Cambodia.
After six ho﻿urs of captivity, the police intervened to release the hostages. During the intervention, a hostage 5-year-old Canadian was killed. Two of thekidnappers were killed, four other orders.
The kidnappers acted byfollowing criminal motivations. Paco Rusconi was released.

name: 2013 Moulin Fournier Cameroun/Nigeria
description:
February 18th, 2013, Tanguy family and Albane Moulin-Fournier as well as their four children and Cyril Moulin-Fournier, brother of Tanguy, are kidnapped while they visited a natural reserve in the North of Cameroon. 

The kidnappers, a group of men in motorcycle, take them in the North of Nigeria. There are several false rumors  on the liberation of the hostages. On February 20th, 2013, the French Secretary Kader Arif asserts wrongly that the hostages are free. On February 24th, Boko-Haram claims the kidnapping of Moulin-Fournier family and asks the liberation of several of their fighters. March 18th, 2013, hostages are freed and return in France on March 20th. 

Several grey areas remain: it would seem that Moulin-Fournier are removed by mistake by a small group of Boko Haram, which would explain their fast liberation. Furthermore, according to the agency Reuters by quoting an official document of the Nigerian government, a 2,4 million euros ransom would have paid and Boko Haram's members freed by Cameroon. 

The French TV channel i>Télé said that a 7 million dollars ransom would have paid and 16 Boko Haram's members freed.  French government and the company GDF-Suez denied.

name: 2011 Nigeria Birnin Kebbi
description:
May 12th, 2011, French ItalianLamolinara and British Chris McManus were deprived of Birnin Kebbi,near the border with Niger.
Bothhostages worked for Stabilini Visinoni Limited, a italian companyspecialized in the batiment and based in Nigeria. They participatedin the construction of a building(ship) of the central Bank ofNigeria to Birnin-Kebbi.
February8th, 2012, Nigerian army and the British Special forces launched anoperation to try to free 2 hostages. At the end of the operation,both hostages were killed by their kidnappers. Franco Lamolinara wasshot four times, including has fatal shot in the head.
Thepresident of Nigeria, Goodluck Jonathan, specified that thekidnappers were members of the Islamist group Boko Haram

name: 2012 Nigeria Francis Collomp
description: Francis Collomp is a French engineer who lives on the Reunion Island (French island in the Indian Ocean). He often worked in Africa. In 2012, he works in Nigeria on a project of wind farm for the company Vergnet, specialized in the renewable energies. He is deprived on December 19th, 2012 of Rimi, in the State of Katsina, in the North of Nigeria, by members of the Islamist group Ansaru. The Islamists kill three people by kidnapping Francis Collomp. The Islamists tell to have kidnapped Francis Collomp in reprisals of the French policy in Mali. He is retained prisoner in several successive places in Nigeria. Last two months of his captivity, he is retained in Zaria, in the State of Kaduna. In November, 2013, he deceives the vigilance of one of his gaolers and succeeds in escaping and in reaching a center of police. He returns in France on November 17th 2013.

name: 2012 Gilberto Rodriguez Mali
description: Gilberto Rodriguez Leal is a French retired man born in Portugal. Former social worker, he lived in the village of Banassac, in Lozère (in the South of France). Fascinated by camper, he had crossed Brazil before leaving for Africa. He is kidnapped on November 20th, 2012. On November 22nd the kidnapping is claimed by the Movement for the uniqueness and the jihad in western Africa. A video of the hostage is broadcast on November 26th, 2012, proving that he is alive. On April 22nd, 2014, the Islamist group announces that it executed Gilberto Rodriguez Leal. No material evidence of this death was brought, but no piece of news of the hostage was given since the announcement of its death.

name: 2011 Mexico Rodolfo Cazares
description: In July, 2011, Rodolfo Cazares and his wife Ludivine Barbier go to vacancy in Rodolfo's family. She lives in the city of Matamoros, in the northeast of Mexico. On July 9th, 2011, Rodolfo, his wife and thirteen other Rodolfo's family members are kidnapped at night. Three days later, hostages are released but Rodolfo remains captive. Kidnappers,  members of the Cartel of the Gulf, ask for a 100 000 dollar ransom. The family pays the ransom, but Rodolfo Cazares is not released. Since 2011, no piece of news of Rodolfo Cazares was given. His wife Ludivine Barbier alerted the French president François Hollande on this captivity, and complains about the lack of reactivity of the French authorities on this case. Quai d'Orsay says to follow the business closely, but refuse to consider Rodolfo Cazares as a hostage because of the absence of political claiming. Ludivine Barbier lodged a complaint in France in 2011 for removal and detention. On February 15th, 2013, she lodged a complaint in Paris with institution of civil action proceedings, which pulled the seizure of investigating judge to investigate into the disappearance of Rodolfo Cazares.

name: 2006 Nigeria Michael Los
description: The Dutch Michael Los, an oil worker, was kidnapped on July 6, 2006, in Nigeria. He was freed on July 10, 2006 after negotiations. According to the authorities, no ransom was paid.

name: 2004 Iraq Salvatore Santoro
description:
On December 15, 2004, an Iraqi group called "Islamic Movement of Iraqi Mujahedeen" claimed credit for the kidnapping of Italian Salvatore Santoro, who was 52. His corpse and passport were shown to an Iraqi photographer. 

Quoting a statement from the kidnappers, Al-Jazeera reported that Santoro had been killed because he supported the American presence in Iraq. Other footage obtained by Qatar-based broadcaster shows alleged members of the group posing with documents apparently taken from the slain man.

There are conflicting reports over why Santoro, who had long lived in Britain, might have been in Iraq.

name: 2004 Libya Marco Vallisa
description:
On July the 5th 2014, Marco Vallisa, an engineer for Piacentini Costruzioni in Libya, was kidnapped in Zuwarah (Libya) together with the Bosnian Petar Matic and the Macedonian Emilio Gafuri. 

The kidnappers asked the Italian government for a ransom of one million euro to release Vallisa a usual practical for the Italian government. On November the 14th 2014, after four months of kidnapping, Vallisa was released.

name: 2008 Somalia Ponant
description: On April 4th, 2008, the luxury sailboat "Le Ponant " is taken by pirates off Somalia. The boat has just ended a cruise and makes road towards the Mediterranean Sea. It has no passengers, but 30 crew members, among whom 22 French people, are present. Pirates require the payment of a two million dollar ransom to free hostages. During the boarding, the captain of the Ponant has time to send a distress message. French military ships, deployed in the Gulf of Aden to fight against the piracy, receive the message and chase after the sailboat. Members of the French special forces are quickly sent on the French military ships. Ponant is taken near the Somalian coast by the pirates and a thirty of them take turns to watch the hostages. April 11th, 2008, hostages are freed and pirates leave the sailboat with their ransom. But once on the ground, a French helicopter pursues them and intercepts six presumed pirates and 200 000 dollars of the ransom aboard a 4x4. A trial takes place in Paris in 2012 in the term which two accused were settled and four condemned to 4 at 10 years of prison.

name: 2011 Mali AQIM Verdon-Lazarevic
description: He is hired with Serge Lazarevic by a malian company to build a cement works. Philippe Verdon is kidnapped with Serge Lazarevic by AQIM of the North of Mali on November 24th, 2011. At the beginning of July 2013, Philippe Verdon's body is found in the North of Mali. He was executed by a bullet in the head by his kidnappers, doubtless for reasons of health. Philippe Verdon indeed suffered from an ulcer and from a palpitation and risked to slow down people of AQIM. Serge Lazarevic, him, will be freed December 9th, 2014 in exchange for the liberation of four terrorists, members of AQIM. Philippe Verdon and Serge Lazarevic were accused of being a member of French secret services, what was denied by the DGSE.

name: 2013 Syria Raqqa
description:
Expelled from Syria in June, 2012, the priest Paolo Dall' Oglio became established in Iraq before returning in secret in Syria, where it was kidnapped on July 29th, 2013 while he tried to obtain the liberation of people held by ISIS. This Jesuit priest had taken the democratic opposition party against the power of president Bachar al-Assad. 
According to some, he is since detained by ISIS. Others believe to know that he was killed or still put back by ISIS to the Syrian regime.

name: 2014 Cameroon Maroua
description:
On April 5th, 2014, three members of a religious order, two Italian priests named Giampaolo Marta and Gianantonio Allegri and a religious Canadian named Gilberte Bussier were kidnapped in their parish of Tchère, in about twenty kilometers of Maroua, in the North of Cameroon.
During their captivity, they were held in Nigeria. 
The kidnappings were not claimed, but the Cameroonian security forces quickly attributed them to the Islamists of the armed Nigerian group Boko Haram.
On June 1st, 2014, three members of a religious order were freed.

name: 2010 Colombia Manuela Fankhauser
description:
The 35-year-old woman, Manuela Fankhauser was kidnapped on January 11, 2010, in the town of Dibulla, about 750 kilometres North of Bogota, where she lived. 

She was released two weeks later on January 23, 2010.  

Police said the captors were demanding 350 thousand US dollars for her liberation.

name: 2005 Yemen German family
description:
Jürgen Chrobog and his family was invited by the Yemeni vice foreign-minister. Jurgen Chrobog 

On December 28, 2005, they were all kidnapped during a cross-country vacation in Eastern Yemen with his wife, Magda, and his three sons, Felix (23), Fabian (25) and Karim (27). They were captured by al-Abdullah ben Dahha tribe. This tribe wanted the liberation of five members of their group, detained by the Yemeni government. 

The family's car had,  initially lagged behind the convoy before finally getting lost. They were detained in a little village of al-Saïd, located at 480 km in the East from Sanaa. They were released on December 31, 2005.

name: 2012 Yemen Finish couple and Dominik Neubauer
description:
The Finnish couple, Leila and Atte Kaleva, along with Austrian Dominik Neubauer, were kidnapped in Sanaa, Yemen, on December 21, 2012 by Yemeni tribesmen. 

They were freed on May 8, 2013, after mediation by authorities in neighboring Oman, who paid a sum of money for their release. 

The Minister added freed hostage Atte Kaleva worked for Finland's Army, without going into further details, but Atte Kaleva had visited Yemen while on leave to study Arabic. Finnish media said Kaleva's wife, Leila, was visiting him when they were kidnapped.

The Austrian hostage, named as Dominik Neubauer, had appeared in a video in February saying that he would be killed within a week if the captors' ransom demands were not met.

name: 2010 Afghanistan Linda Norgrove
description:
Linda Norgrove, a 36 years British aid worker employed by US aid group Development Alternatives Incorporated (DAI), was kidnapped in Afghanistan on September 26, 2010 by an Afghan group. Her car was forced off the road in Kunar province, near the Pakistan border.

Soon after her abduction, she was taken to a stronghold in a steep-sided valley in the mountains of northern Kunar. But her kidnappers were being watched by US intelligence. They had a network of informers in the area and drones circling above. 

She was killed on October 8, 2010, when US Navy Seals stormed her captors’ base trying to rescue her, by the blast from a grenade thrown by one of the American soldiers.

name: 2012 Philippines wildlife photographers
description:
Lorenzo Vinciguerra, 49 years old, is a Swiss wildlife photographer who was held hostage by Abu Sayyaf Islamist group for more than two years. He was seized with Ewold Horn, a Dutch photographer, while sailing in Southern Philippines in February 2012. The two men were on a bird-watching trip in Tawi-Tawi province when they were kidnapped by rebels of the Abu Sayyaf group. 

He escaped on 6th December 2014 by cutting his captor's throat with a machete during a clash between insurgents and governments troops in the southern Philippines. 

Philippine army scout rangers later found Lorenzo Vinciguerra and escorted him to safety. He then fled from his abductors, who had been keeping him on the southern island of Jolo, Mindanao. 

Horn was too sick to escape.

name: 2012 Syria
description:
John Cantlie was kidnapped a second time on November 22, 2012. He was seized with his friend, the american journalist James Foley. They were about to pass the border to Syria when they were kidnapped in their taxi. They had first been held by the Nusra Front, a al-Qaeda affiliated group before to be held by the Islamic State. Jihadists asked for ransoms. James Foley was beheaded on August 19, 2014, by Jihadi John, a british IS fighter. 

John Cantlie is still held by the Jihadists. According to former IS hostages, he has been tortured. He appeared his several IS propaganda videos. The last took place in Aleppo. 

John Cantlie, 44, is a british journalist and war correspondant. He had been working for The Sunday Times andThe Sunday Telegraph. He had been abducted a first time in July 2012, with the Dutch photographer Jeroen Oerlemans. They were rescued by the Free Syrian Army.

name: 2012 Syria Bab al-Hawa
description:
John Cantlie, 44, is a British journalist and war correspondant. He worked for The Sunday Times andThe Sunday Telegraph. Together with another Dutch freelance photographer, Jeroen Oerelmans they were abducted on July 19, 2012, near Bab al-Hawa, at the border between Syria and Turkey.

They both tried to escape but failed. They were both injured during the attempt. Their captors wanted to keep them in captivity to ask for a ransom. They were rescued and freed on July 26, 2012 by members of the Free Syrian Army.

name: 2012 India Two Italian tourists
description:
On March 14, 2012, two Italian tourists, Paolo Bosusco and Claudio Colangelo, were taken hostage in the State of Orissa, in the east of India, by Maoist rebels.

Having kidnapped both Italians, the kidnappers had stated thirteen claims as the stop of security forces'operations, the end of tourism in the tribal zones and the liberation of Maoist prisoners.

11 days after being taken hostage, Claudio Colangelo was released unharmed by ultras on March 25, 2012.

After nearly a month in captivity, Paolo Bosusco was released on April 12, 2012.

name: 2005 Iraq Giuliana Sgrena
description: On February 4, 2005, Italian journalist Giuliana Sgrena, a correspondent for Il Manifesto, was kidnapped in Baghdad. She was freed a month later on March 4, also in Baghdad. She was injured shortly after her release by American troops shootings at the convoy taking her to the airport in Baghdad. A member of the Italian secret services was killed in the incident.

name: 2007 Nigeria Port Harcourt
description:
Margaret Hill, a three-year old British little girl, was seized by gunmen while she was going to school in Port Harcourt, Nigeria, July 5, 2007. Her father was an oil worker in the Niger Delta. 

Her kidnappers asked for a ransom. The MEND (Niger Delta militants taking hostages to achieve their political goals) proposed to help the authorities to find Margaret Hill.  

She was released unarmed three days later. Her family said they didn't pay a ransom.

name: 2010 Nigeria Port Harcourt
description:
Britons John Bennett, Kevin Gray and Martin Phillips were three oil workers in Niger Delta, Nigeria. They were kidnapped with a fourth man : Colombian Fabien Sánchez.

They were seized on January 12, 2010 by a group of 40 men,  on their usual route to work at a power plant in Afam, east of Port Harcourt.  A Nigerian security officer died during the attack. 

They all were freed on January 18, 2010, after six days of captivity. No reason was given for their release. Medias said their captors claimed a $2 million ransom.

name: 2006 Nigeria Port Harcourt
description:
Six persons were abducted in Niger Delta, on October 3, 2006. Among them were, four Britons - Paul Smith, George McLean, Sandy Cruden, Graeme Buchana - a Romanian, a Malaysian and an Indonesian. They were seized while they were at a bar with friends, in Port Harcourt, Nigeria. Several persons died during the attack.

The captors wanted £21 millions in order to free the hostages. They were all freed after 18 days of captivity, on October 21, 2006, but authorities said they had no information about the release.

During the captivity, media said Paul Smith had been killed, but it happened to be false.

name: 2011 Kenya Judith Tebbutt
description:
Briton Judith Tebbutt, a 56 years-old social worker, was on holidays with her husband David Tebbutt (a publishing executive), in the Kiwayu Safari Village, in Kenya. 

During the night of September 11, 2011, Somalian Pirates entered in their bungalow, killed David Tebbutt and kidnapped Judith Tebbutt. Her captors took her to Somalia. On March 21, 2012, Judith Tebbutt was released after six months of captivity. 

Her family paid a ransom of $1million. Judith's son, Oliver raised the money thanks to friends and relatives. It was air-dropped to the kidnappers.

name: 2005 Rafah Palestine
description:
Briton Kate Burton, 24, was an aid worker at the al-Mezan human rights centre, in Gaza, Palestine. She was kidnapped with her parents, on December 28, 2005. 
Hugh, 73, and Helen, 55, were visiting their daughter. They all were abducted near the Palestinian-Egyptian border, while they were visiting the city of Rafah. 
Their captors  called themselves the "Mujahadeen Brigades" and treated well the hostages. In a video, they denounced the attitude and the actions of the british government in Palestine, since 1918. They demanded a promise that UK and European Union would help to end the Israeli occupation in Gaza. 
The family was released on December 30, 2005, at a gunpoint in Gaza, after two days of captivity.

name: 2008 Carré d'As Somalia
description: Jean-Yves and Bernadette Delanne are a couple of sailors. While they escorted the sailboat ' Carré d'As ' between Australia and France, they are attacked by pirates off Somalia on September 2nd, 2008. The couple is held as hostage on the sailboat. The pirates ask for a 8 millions dollars ransom, then finally of 2 millions in the face of the intransigence of the French authorities. They also demand the liberation of their companions, culprits to have participated in the taking of hostages on the sailboat ' Le Ponant '. At night from 15 till 16 September 2008, a French commando squad frees the hostages, kills a pirate and captures six other presents on board. The hostages and the pirates are returned in France. Judged in France in 2013  justice decided on four prison sentences going from 4 to 8 years of reclusion and an acquittal.

name: 2011 Yemen French Hostages
description: Three French humanitarian workers were in the Yemen to work on projects of irrigation in the southeast of the country. They are kidnapped on May 28th, 2011 by men of AQAP. The kidnappers let know that they will free them in exchange for a 12 million euro ransom. In September, 2011, a video proves that hostages are alive. The negotiations between the kidnappers and the French services are facilitated by the sultan of Oman, who plays a determining role in the liberation of the hostages. While three humanitarian workers found the freedom at night from 13 till 14 November 2011, the French government assures that it did not pay ransom to the kidnappers.

name: 2011 Somalia Marie Dedieu
description:
Marie Dedieu was a 66-year-old Frenchwoman who lived on the Kenyan island of Manda since fifteen years. Former feminist activist in 1970s, she had retired in the Indian Ocean. 

On October 1, 2011, she was abducted by around 10 armed men who arrived in speed boats at her beach front home on Manda Island. 
Shebabs, the Somalian Islamist group, denied being at the origin of this hostage taking.

She was sick and she died in captivity.

name: 2014 Algeria Hervé Gourdel
description:
The French citizen Hervé Gourdel, 55 years old, was kidnapped with five Algerians walkers in the Mountain of Djudjura in Algeria, on September 22th, 2014.

The Algerian terrorist group Jund al-Khalifa, which announce the kidnapping, is referring to the Islamic State.

The four Algerian are freed immediately because "they are muslim".

They threat to kill Hervé Gourdel within 24 hours if France does not stop his intervention against the terrorist group Islamic State in Iraq.

Hervé Gourdel is decapitated on September 23th, 2014 by Jund al-Khalifa. The video of the murder is published on YouTube the same day.

name: 2011 / 2012 Algeria Maria Sandra Mariani
description:
On February 2nd, 2011, Maria Sandra Mariani, an Italian tourist, was taken hostage in the region of Ilidina, in the southeast of Algeria, by a group of 14 men armed from AQIM, managed by Abou Zeid. She was with a driver and a guide, who were shortly after released. 
During her detention, the Italian would have been moved in two or three countries.
On April 17th, 2012, she was released at the age of 54. She was taken by the authorities of Burkina Faso in Tessalit, in the North of Mali.

name: November 2006 - Niger Delta Tanker
description:
Seven people were taken hostage during the attack launched against a tanker of the company Saipem, the subsidiary engineering of the Italian oil group Eni, in Nigeria. 
Seven people, whom an Italian employee of Saipem, were taken hostage during the assaulted by ten men armed with the boat Mystras, managed by Saipem and by the company SBM, parking on the deposit ofOkono, off Port-Harcourt.
The Nigerian army launched an attack to release the foreign hostages. A British hostage was killed during this operation. The Italian hostage was hurt. Among the hostages appeared, besides the British, twoFinns, the Italian, the Filipino, the Pole and the Romanian.

name: 2005 / 2006 Venezuela Anita Capuozzo
description:
On August 20th, 2005, a resident Italian in Venezuela was kidnapped by unknowns while she went for jogging near her place of residence, in the luxurious district of Lagunita, in the southeast of Caracas. 

She was held in a farm, far from Caracas.

On September 1st, 2006, the woman, healthy, was freed.

name: 2006 Nigeria Buguma Kidnapping
description:
On May 11th, three expatriates, whom an Italian, working for the oil company Saipem, were kidnapped in Buguma, in the South of Nigeria.
It is about a conflict with villagers, these not being satisfied with Saipem. 

On May 12th, three people are freed. 

From the beginning of 2006, the region of the Delta of Niger is the theater of violence against oil companies and their employees, separatist groups and local communities asking for more economic effects from the oil basket, got according to them by the international major companies and some corrupt politicians

name: 2006 Yemen Italian Tourists
description:
Five Italian tourists, three women and two men, were kidnapped on January 1, 2006 in Yemen by members of a tribe and were freed on January 6. 

Three women had been released on January 1st by their kidnappers, but they refused to abandon their two companions.

The Italians were put back to tribal leaders committed in the mediation. Their kidnappers were arrested. They wanted the released of their imprisoned comrades.

name: 2006 Israel Gilad Shalit
description:
Gilad Shalit, an Israeli soldier, and his crew were attacked on June 25, 2006 by two Palestinian activists near the border of the Gaza Strip. His companions were killed and Gilad Shalit was removed and taken in the Gaza Strip.

Several organizations claimed the removal: Ezzedine al-Qassam brigades, the Committee of popular resistance and the Army of the Islam. The Israeli army did not succeed in locating Gilad Shalit and launched the operation "Summer Rains" on the Gaza Strip.

Several senior officials of the movement were made prisoners. After long negotiations, the group made a commitment to free Gilad Shalit. Egyptian and German services served a time of intermediaries.

The Hamas required the liberation of Palestinian prisoners. At first, Israeli government refused. While the Palestinians considered Gilad Shalit as a war prisoner, the Israelis considered him as a hostage, his kidnappers having refused the visits of Red Cross. I

n Israel, the family of Gilad Shalit mobilized public opinion to obtain his liberation. Gilad Shalit became a national symbol and his liberation was asked by numerous countries. Several demonstrations of supports were organized in France, because he also had the French nationality.

Detained in the Gaza Strip, he was finally released on October 18, 2011 in exchange for more than 1000 Palestinian prisoners. Some debates however burst after his liberation, his numerous errors were said to have facilitated his capture.

name: 2008-2009 Somalia ACF Workers
description: On November 5, 2008, four NGO worker along with two Kenyan pilots were seized by more than twenty gunmen in Somalia. The two French women, a Belgian and a Bulgarian working for Action Contre La Faim (ACF - Action Against Hunger) boarded a plane and were flown out of Somalia, a spokeswoman for the NGO said. The French presidency announced their release on August 11, 2009.

name: 2006 Iraq Greek NGO
description: A Greek NGO worker in Iraq, whose name wasn't revealed, has been abducted by a group of armed men on October 31, 2006. She's been freed three days later by Iraq security forces, the general Abdel Karim Khalaf told AFP.

name: 2011 Greek Hostages in Nigeria
description:
A Greek oil tanker has been hijacked and its crew taken hostage off the coast of Nigeria on July 16, 2011 by a group of armed men. The tanker named “Aegean Star” pertained to the Endeavour Marine Agency company and was headed towards Benin. Twenty people have been taken hostages, including three Greek workers (the ship captain’s included).

Greek coastguards announced the liberation of the hostages, in a healthy condition, on July 18, 2011. Officials didn’t specify wether a ransom was paid.

name: 2009 Chad Laurent Maurice
description:
Laurence Maurice is a french humanitarian worker for "International Committee of the Red Cross". He was kidnapped on November 9th, 2009 in the east of the Chad.

He had been captured by several men armed in the Chadian village of Coffee, in about ten kilometers of the Sudanese border.

The group that kidnapped him, the "Freedom Eagles of Africa", had demanded a million euros to release him.

No ransom would have been paid according to the ICRC and the French government. Laurence Maurice had been freed February 6th, 2010.

name: 2004 Iraq Italian Journalist Baldoni
description:
Enzo Baldoni, a correspondent for the Milan weekly Diario, was captured by a group calling itself The Islamic Army on August 20, 2004 on a road between Baghdad and the southern city of Najaf.

The group released footage of the hostage on August 24, 2004 and gave the Italian government 48 hours to announce a troop pullout from Iraq. Italy  refused, but Foreign Minister Franco Frattini later said on the Al-Jazeera television news channel that his country was prepared to pull its troops out of Iraq if the interim government in Baghdad requested it. Baldoni was executed. Al-Jazeera said on August 26, 2004 that it had received a videotape showing the journalist after his execution, but did not broadcast the footage.

Enzo Baldoni's remains were identified in August 2005.

name: 2001 Philippines Italian Priest
description: Giuseppe Pierantoni was kidnapped on October 17, 2001 by a group called Pentagon in Dimataling in the southern Philippines. He abductors demanded for $US 196,000 dollars. On April 7, 2002 Pierantoni was released after several exchanges of gunfire with government forces. Four other hostages were still being held by Pentagon group after the release of the Italian priest.

name: 2004 Iraq The two Simona
description:
On September 6, 2004 Simona Pari and Simona Torretta, volunteers for the Italian NGO Ponte Per, were kidnapped in Baghdad at the office of their organisation along with two Iraqi engineers. A group called Ansar Al-Zawahir claimed responsibility for the abduction. 

Public pressure in Italy mounted, calling for the release of the 'two Simonas', with the Vatican also calling for them to be freed.  The hostages were let go on September 28, 2004 after a one million dollar ransom was paid.

name: 2004 Iraq Italian Hostages
description:
Four Italian members of a security agency working in Iraq were kidnapped on April 12, 2004.

Fabrizio Quattrocchi, 36, from Catania was accused by his kidnappers of being a "soldier of fortune" and was executed the same day. His kidnappers sent a video of the execution to TV station Al Jazeera, but it was not broadcast. His death  shocked Italy, and prompted the Vatican to propose mediation for the release of the other hostages. 

His body was repatriate to Italy on May, 24, 2004.

During this period Italian Prime Minister Berlusconi declared that Italian military troops would stay in Iraq. On June 8, 2004 the Italian government confirmed the release of the three remaining hostages -- Mauricio Agliana, Salvatore Stefio and Umberto Cupertino. Another hostage from Poland was released at the same time.

name: 2011 Niamey French Hostages
description: Antoine de Léocour and Vincent Delory are kidnapped on January 7th, 2011 by four men of AQIM in Niamey, the capital of Niger. Embarked in pick-up, they are quickly chased by the gendarmerie of Niger and the French servicemen. While the Islamists run towards their base to Mali, the French special forces try to intercept them. An exchange of shootings follows, during whom the hostages die. If he makes hardly doubt which Antoine de Léocour was executed by the Islamists, doubts remain on the conditions of Vincent Delory's death. According to certain testimonies, the young man would have died burned further to the explosion of the 4x4 which transported him, affected by French shootings.

name: 2004 Saudi Arabia Khobar Attack
description:
Islamic militants attacked two oil industry facilities and a residence in al-Khobar, Saudi Arabia on July 29, 2004. During the attacks, 22 people were killed, including one foreign national each from Italy, Sweden and the United Kingdom.  Some 25 hostages were also taken, mostly at a residential compound known as The Oasis.  

Hostages were rescued during a Saudi commando operation the next day. Credit for the attack was claimed by Abdulaziz al-Muqrin, a member of Al-Qaeda in Saudi Arabia. Security forces shot him a few weeks later in Riyadh, the Saudi capital.

name: 2010 Central African Republic Denis / Frappé
description:
Olivier Denis and Olivier Frappe were working for a French charity, Triangle Generation Humanitaire, when they were kidnapped in November, 22th, 2009 in the Central African Republic, across the border from the western region of Sudan.

Two French aid workers abducted in the Central African Republic and held for four months by Freedom Eagles of Africa.

They were released in March, 14th, 2010, in Darfur, the Sudanese region gripped by civil war and a wave of kidnappings.

name: 2010 Pakistan Greek hostage
description: Athanassios Lerounis, a Greek humanitarian worker has been held hostage during seven months in Pakistan. Abducted on September 09, 2009, he has been released on April 07, 2010. A ransom and the liberation of three prisonners have been asked but the hostage has been freed without conditions.

name: 2003 / 2004 Venezuela Stéphanie Minana
description:
Stéphanie Minana,was kidnapped by a group of six to eight men in western Venezuela on December 8, 2003 as she exited a restaurant in the town of Valera, 400 miles from Caracas.  A student in Spanish, she had taken a sabbatical year to be with her brother.

Her abductors demanded a two million euro ransom, and were still negotiating when Minana was freed on January 23, 2004 by a special forces commando unit.  No money was paid.

During the rescue, two hostage takers were killed and a third fled. The leader of the gang was later identified and arrested.

name: 2010 Nigeria Movement for the emancipation of the delta of Niger
description: Patrick Weber and Gilles Mignon were kidnapped on November 7th, 2010 on an oil rig of the company Afren, off Nigeria. 19 other people were made prisoners, among whom two Americans, two Canadians and two Indonesians, the other people being Nigerians. The kidnapping of 14 hostages, which both French people, is claimed by the Movement for the emancipation of the delta of Niger, which militates for a distribution of the incomes from the oil. Armed Nigerian succeeds in releasing 19 hostages who were detained in the State of Rivers, in the South of Nigeria. According to her, no ransom was paid. The French hostages were released with othres on November 17th, 2010.
