name: 2011 Darfur Bulgarian Workers
description:
Three Bulgarian air crew members working for the United Nations have been abducted by a group of strangers in Darfur on January 13, 2011. They were working for the UN World Food Program.  

According to Branko Tchorbadjiyski, one of the hostages, the liberation of the Bulgarian workers on June 06, 2011, wasn't the result of an armed intervention. No ransom has been paid.

name: 2004 Iraq Fallujah - Bony et al.
description:
A team of French TV reporters from  France 2 were abducted on May 26 and held for almost 24 hours in Fallujah, Iraq. The kidnappers made reference to a newly passed law in France banning the wearing of religious symbols, widely perceived as targeting young Muslims wearing veils.

The four men were: journalist Jérôme Bony, cameraman Jean-François Renoux, sound engineer Eric Giet, and interpreter Muthanna. They were in Fallujah to do a story on the enforcement of Islamic law.

They were kidnapped while  having lunch in a restaurant, and released the next morning. It is not thought that a ransom was paid.

name: 2004 Iraq Chesnot Malbrunot
description:
Frenchmen Christian Chesnot and Georges Malbrunot were abducted in Iraq on August 20, 2004 by the Islamic Army in Iraq, along with their Syrian driver Mohamed Al-Joundi.

The kidnappers said that their captives would be freed if the French government cancelled a newly-adopted law on secularism in France within 48 hours.

The law was not rescinded, but Chesnot and Malbrunot were freed on December 21,2004 after 124 days.

Rumors that a large ransom of up to 11,800,000 euros was paid for their release were denied by the French Government.

name: 2006 Niger Delta Tanker
description:
Milko Nichev was abducted on January 11, 2006, along with three other employees of Tidewater, a Shell contractor. A British worker, Nigel Watson-Clark, was among the hostages, along with a Hondurian and an American.

The hostages have been abducted by a group of Nigerian separatist rebels. They asked a ransom of 1,5 billion dollars and the liberation of two members of the Ijaw separatists.

The hostages were freed on January 30, 2006. Milko Nichev later said he didn't know if a ransom had been paid.

name: 2010 Nigeria Pirates Bourbon
description:
Three French and a Thai were abducted on September 22, 2010. They were sailors working on a boat operating on an oil field off Nigeria.

They are sailors for the French company Bourbon, a group of maritimes services for the petroleum industry. Bourbon was already confronted three times since August, 2008 with kidnappings of collaborators in Nigeria, where the phenomenon is current.

Every time the hostages have been released shortly after. The identity of the hostages and the kidnappers was not communicated by the company, officially for safety reasons. But apparently, it is pirates who kidnapped the sailors of Bourbon. The negotiations led before any summer by this company and the British secret services, which know very well this zone of Africa. According to the magazine Le Point, Bourbon would have paid 150 000 $ to obtain the liberation of the hostages, but this information was not confirmed by the group.

They were released on November 10, 2013.

name: 2004 Bagdad Iraq Jordanov Ceriex
description: French journalists Alexandre Jordanov, working for news agency CAPA, and Ivan Ceriex, working for French TV station Canal Plus, were abducted in southern Baghdad on April 11, 2004. Both were kidnapped while filming an attack on an American convoy.  Ceriex was released a few hours later. Jordanov was released three days later on April 14.  Their abductors were thought to be Sunni fighters.

name: 2004 Colombia Julien Fouchet
description: French law student and freelance radio reporter Julien Fouchet, 27, was kidnapped by the Colombian right-wing militia group United Self-Defense Forces (AUC) in the department of Magdalena,  some 1,000 km north of Bogota.  He was set free on February 29, 2004.

name: 2002 Russia Lionel Malabar
description:
French national Lionel Malabar, 53 years old, was kidnapped at Sheremetyevo Airport in Russia, on December 12, 2002.

A gang from Azerbaidjian that had lured him to Russia with the help of an attractive young woman held him for a 900,000 euros ($US 924,000) ransom. 

He was taken to a house in the village of Tchekov outside Moscow. The kidnappers beat Malabar and forced him to call his relatives and ask them to pay the ransom. French and Russian polices intervened, and freed him on December 19, 2002.

No ransom was given according to the authorities.

name: 2002 Colombia Galipon
description:
French national Pierre Galipon, 46, co-pilot of a Bell helicopter 212, made an emergency landing on April 19th, 2002 in the Andean mountains of Colombia. He was has held hostage by the FARC (Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia ) along with  two Canadians, Gilles Pregent, age 50, also a pilot, and mechanic Jay Riddel, 30.

Galipon and his co-crew members was released by the FARC on an island in the river Patia, near the Pacific on July, 31th, 2002.

name: 2000 Somalia Françoise Deutsch
description:
Françoise Deutsch was working in Somalia as an administrator for the NGO Action Against the Hunger (ACF).

She was kidnapped, July, 25th, 2000 with a British colleague, Jonathan Ward, at ACF's base camp situated in the South of Mogadishu.

Their kidnappers freed them on September 18, 2000.

name: 2000 Philippines Jolo kidnapping
description:
Twenty-one persons were abducted on April 23, 2000 from the Malaysian resort of Sipadan by the Muslim rebel group Abu Sayyaf. They included 10 tourists from Europe, the Middle East and South Africa, as well as 11 Malaysian resort workers -- 19 non-Filipino nationals in total. 

Five foreign hostages were released on August 27, 2000. French television reporter Maryse Burgot, Lebanese-born French woman Marie Moarbes, French woman Sonia Wendling and German Werner Wallert were allegedly set free after a ransom, reportedly of 1 million US dollars per head.

German Marc Wallert, Frenchman Stephane Loisy, Finns Seppo Fränti and Risto Vahanen and a Filipino resort worker were released on September 10, 2000.

name: 2010 Niger hostages Areva
description:
September 16th, 2010, seven people - five French people, among whom a woman, a Togolese and a Malagasy - were abducted in Arlit, a site of extraction of uranium in the North of Niger by AQIM. Daniel and Françoise Larribe, Pierre Legrand, Thierry Dol and Marc Ferret were the five French held in captivity. 

On February 24, 2011, Frenchwoman, Françoise Larribe, wife of Daniel, as well as the Togolese and the Malagasy, were freed "on territory of Niger".

 On March 21st of the same year, AQIM demanded " at least 90 million euros" for the liberation of the four French people still hostages, the request was rejected by France. 

The hostages were detained in the massif of Ifoghas, in the North of Mali. In January, 2013, when the operation Serval was launched by the French president François Hollande in Mali, the fate of the hostages became more and more uncertain. In Mali, border country of Niger, a security source declared that the "last negotiations " on their liberation "took place in the Malian desert". 

The last four French hostages were freed at the end of October 2013 and welcomed to Paris on October 29th, 2013. According to the former American ambassadress, France would have paid 17 million dollars for the liberation of the hostages. According to a source close to negotiators of Niger, France would paid a ransom between 20 and 25 millions dollars. but this information was denied by the French government. Laurent Fabius, the French minister of Foreign Office, said that there was not "public money" at stake, but he had said nothing about "private money".

name: 1999 Russia Grozny hostages
description:
French photojournalist Brice Fleutiaux and two scientists from Poland were kidnapped on October 1, 1999 in Grozny by a Chechen group. Fleutiaux was released on June 12, 2000 in exchange for a Chechen war chief and for guarantees of safety for other fighters.

The fate of the two scientists is unknown, they are presumed dead.

name: 2009 Afghanistan Hervé Ghesquière and Stéphane Taponier
description: Hervé Ghesquière and Stéphane Taponier were kidnapped on December 30th, 2009 by the Talibans in the province of Kapisa, in Afghanistan. Presents to do a report for the broadcast "Pieces of evidence", they are kidnapped with their translator while the zone was supposed to be kept by the French army. Both journalists are often moved and are separated in April 8th, 2010. They will find themselves on December 13th, 2010. In the term of several months of negotiation, they are put back on June 29th, 2011 to the French army of the base of Tagab in Afghanistan.

name: 2004 Kabul Afghanistan
description:
Annetta Flanigan from Northern Ireland, a UN election worker, was kidnapped on October 28, 2004 in Kabul along with two colleagues, Shqipe Habibi of Kosovo and Angelito Nayan, a Philippine diplomat. A group called Jaish-e-Muslimeen (the Army of Muslims) took credit for the abduction. The kidnappers said they would kill the hostages unless U.N. and foreign troops left Afghanistan, and Taliban and al Qaeda prisoners were freed from military jails in Guantanamo and Afghanistan. 

Afghan authorities confirmed that the hostages were kidnapped by Jaish-e-Muslimeen – whose leader, Sayed Mohammed Akbar Agha, had broken away from Taliban leader Mohammad Omar -- but said the hostages had been seized initially by a criminal gang, perhaps hired by the group. The three captives were released on November 22, 2004, after 27 days of captivity.

name: 2010 Pakistan Waziristan
description:
Asad Qureshi, 53, a British documentary film-maker, was kidnapped on March 26, 2010 by a militant group called the "Asian Tigers" in North Waziristan (tribal zone) in Pakistan. He was abducted with his driver, Rustam Khan, and two former senior members of Pakistan's intelligence agency, who were acting as guides : Khalid Khawaja and Colonel Imam (real name : Sultan Amir Tarar) who worked with the mujahideen resistance to the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan, in the 1980s. 

Asad Qureshi and his driver were released on September 9, 2010, after 165 days of captivity. The kidnappers had demanded $10 million and the release of several Taliban prisoners in return for Asad Qureshi's freedom, but it is not clear whether any of their demands were met.

Khalid Khawaja was executed in April 2010. Colonel Imam was executed in January 2011. His exetutors refused to give back his body to his family, unless a ransom would be paid. Usman Punjabi who planned their kidnap was killed two weeks before Asad Qureshi's release and Sabir Mehsud, the leader of the Asian Tigers was himself kidnapped by Hakimullah Mehsud.

name: 2005 Bagdad Iraq
description:
Kenneth Bigley was taken hostage with Americans Jack Hensley and Eugene Armstrong, on September 16, 2004. They all were working on construction projects in Iraq. 

Their captors were members of the Tawhid and Jihad, an Islamic extremist group, led by Jordanian Abu Musab al-Zarqawi. 

On a video, they said they would kill the men in 48 hours if their demands were not satisfied. They asked for the release of two Iraqi women prisoners : Rihab Taha Huda Salih Mahdi Ammash. Those two women participated to Iraq's biological-weapons program, according to the UN. 

Eugene Armstrong was killed on September, 20 when the deadline expired, Hensley Hensley the next day, and Kenneth Bigley two weeks later. They all were beheaded. Videos of the executions were sent to the medias.

name: 2005 Iraq Phillip Sands Kidnapping
description:
Phillip Sands, 28,  was a freelance reporter for the San Francisco Chronicle and The Scotsman. He was abducted on December 26, 2005, with his interpreter and driver, in Baghdad. His captors were gunmen who planned on using them to force British troops to leave Iraq and release all Iraqi prisoners. 

The gunmen identified themselves only as Sunni Muslims. On December 31, 2005, Phillip and his two colleagues were rescued by the american forces.

name: 2009 Afghanistan Stephen Farrell
description:
In 2009, Stephen Farrell, a british journalist working for The New York Times, and his interpreter, Sultan Munadi were kidnapped on September 5, after they had travelled to a US site in the northern province of Kunduz, in Afghanistan.

Four days later, on September 9, Stephen Farell was rescued in a military operation but his interpreter and a woman and child were killed in the assault. A british soldier and a Taliban also died. 

Stephen Farell was criticized because it seemed that he ignored many warnings that it was too dangerous to travel to this area.

name: 2004 Iraq Fallujah - Stephen Farell
description: In April 2004, while working for The Times, British journalist Stephen Farell was kidnapped by Sunni insurgents during the so-called First Battle of Fallujah. He was freed after eight hours of captivity. He said he was freed when he managed to convince his captors that he was a genuine journalist.

name: 2004 Iraq Margaret Hassan
description:
Briton Margaret Hassan, 59, a humanitarian worker in Iraq since 1992, was kidnapped in southern Baghdad on October 19, 2004. In a video released by her captors, she said that the withdrawal of British troops from Iraq was a condition for her release.  

Hassan was killed on November 8, 2004. Al-Jazeera said the broadcaster received a video showing her execution but was unable to confirm its authenticity. The group responsible for her kidnapping and death never identified itself, and her body was never found.

name: 2007 Iraq British hostages
description:
Five British men were seized at Baghdad's Ministry of Finance, on May 29, 2007. Their captors, a group of 40 men, were dressed as policemen. Four of them, Jason Creswell, Jason Swindlehurst, Alec McLachlan and Alan McMenemy, were security guards. The man they were protecting - IT expert Peter Moore - was seized too. 

Their captors were Shia militiamen who demanded the withdrawal of British troops from Iraq and the release of all Iraqi prisoners.One of the kidnappers said that Jason Creswell, Jason Swindlehurst and Alec Maclachlan, were quickly killed after the British government refused to pay a ransom.

The bodies of Jason Swindlehurst and Jason Creswell were recovered on June 19, 2009. On July 29, 2009, it was revealed that Alec Maclachlan and Alan McMenemy had also been killed. 

Peter Moore was released on December 30, 2009 afterr the release of Qais Khazali, a leader of the Righteous League. This organization is linked to the Iranian Revolutionary Guard's elite unit, the al-Quds forces.

name: 2006 Nigeria Niger Delta
description:
John Hudspith was kidnapped on February 18, 2006, in southern Nigeria. He was abducted with 8 others oil workers on a barge near a pipeline in the Niger delta. The militants from the MEND (Movement for the Emancipation of the Niger Delta) were demanding Nigeria's government release two of their leaders. They also wanted the government to share the profits from the oil pumped in the Delta.

The first men released was the American Macon Hawkins because he was a diabetic. The group released 5 of the captives (two Egyptians, two Thais, and one Filipino) after 12 days. 

Americans Cody Oswalt, Russell Spell and Briton John Hudspith were released on March 27, 2006, after more than five weeks in captivity. Officially, no ransom was paid.

name: 2004 Iraq Bulgarian hostages
description:
Truck drivers Georgy Lazov and Ivailo Kepov, both Bulgarian nationals, were taken hostages in Iraq on July 8, 2004 near the city of Mosul. The two men were transporting second-hand cars from Turkey. Credit for the kidnapping was claimed by Tawhid wal Jihad (Unity and Holy War), reportedly led by top Al-Qaeda operative Abu Mussab al-Zarqawi, a Jordanian thought to have orchestrated dozens of deadly attacks in Iraq. The group threatened to kill the hostages unless US troops free Iraqi prisoners within 24 hours.

The two men were beheaded. The body of Georgy Lazov was identified on July 22, and that of Ivailo Kepov on August 11 of the same year.

name: 2005 Iraq Bernard Planche Kidnapping in Baghdad
description:
Bernard Planche, a 52 years old engineer, was abducted in Iraq in 2005. He moved to Iraq to work with an aid agency which specialises in water distribution. Uncertainty about Planche's work in Iraq, for a virtually unknown aid group specialising in water distribution, and the circumstances of his release fueled media speculation over the true reason for his presence in the war-torn country. Several French intelligence officials denied that he was linked to the secret services. One official, speaking on condition of anonymity, described Planche as a "loner", saying he was "not a member of the French intelligence services". Another said Planche was a "desperado" but not a spy.

Bernard Planche managed to escape the farmhouse were he was held after 35 days of captivity, on January 7, 2006. The military said his captors had suddenly abandoned the farm to avoid a patrol of US and Iraqi troops in the area.

name: 2001 Colombia Aïda Duvaltier
description:
Aïda Duvaltier and her husband Jean-Marie Duvaltier were the owners of a small isolated farm in Arma, located in the western mountains of Colombia. On the afternoon of March 6, 2001 guerrillas of the Popular Army of Liberation ( EPL), a Maoist group, went to the farm. After several hours of discussion, the kidnappers took Aïda Duvaltier, then 67-year-old, in the Andes mountains, which they used as a shelter and refuge. The EPL -- composed mostly of soldiers demobilized in the 1990s, funding itself mostly with kidnappings and extorsion. 

Aïda's body was discovered on February 12, 2006 near the municipality of Quinchia, 430 km west of Bogota. Police received a tip as to its location from a confessions of an EPL fighter who had deserted.

name: 2008 Pakistan Polish hostage execution
description:
Piotr Stanczak, 42, was working as a geologist in Pakistan for a Polish oil and natural gas exploration company. He has been abducted in the volatile northwest of the country on September 28. His kidnappers killed his driver and his bodyguard.

The security adviser to Prime Minister Donald Tusk, Jacek Cichocki, said the kidnappers had originally demanded the release of 60 Islamist fighters held in Pakistan but eventually watered down their demands to just four. Stanczak's captors also wanted Poland to pull out the 1,600 troops it has deployed in Afghanistan as part of the UN-mandated and NATO-led International Security Assistance Force (ISAF). On Feb 10, Poland offered a 290,000 dollars (224,000 euros) reward for any information leading to the Talibans responsible for the death of Piotr Stanczac. Polish authorities have also requested US assistance to help capture Stanczak's killers.

On May 31, Shah Abdul Aziz, a former Pakistani parlementarian, has been arrested in connection with the abduction and murder of the geologist. Attaullah Khan, one of Stanczak's alleged killers, had been arrested on July 16 in Islamabad and gave Aziz’s name, according to Polish news agency PAP, citing Pakistani media reports. Attaullah Khan said that Aziz’s asked him to kill Stanczak, according to Reuters.

name: 2002 Colombia Ingrid Betancourt
description:
French national Ingrid Betancourt, a Green Party candidate in Colombia's presidential election, and her campaign manager Clara Rojas were taken prisoner on February 23, 2002 by the FARC -- Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia -- near Florencia, some 600 km southeast of Bogota. Betancourt and Rojas ventured into this dangerous area after authorities refused to allow them to travel by plane with journalists accompanying President André Pastrana.

Four days after the kidnapping, the guerrilla group proposed an exchange for rebels prisoners.

After several attempts at liberation and years of fruitless negotiation, the Colombian national army launched 'Operation Jaque', ending Betancourt's long captivity in July, 2008. Among the 15 people freed, Ingrid Betancourt  was the most high-profile FARC hostage.

name: 2004 Iraq James Brandon
description:
James Brandon, 23 , working as a freelance journalist for The Sunday Telegraph, was kidnapped in Iraq on August 13, 2004. He was abducted in his hotel in Basra by some 30 gunmen. His captors threatened to kill him if US forces did leave the city of Najaf, in the south of Iraq within the next 24 hours.

The Shia leader Moqtada al-Sadr intervened Brandon's behalf, and the Briton was released on August 13, 2004 to Sadr's Basra office. He had clearly been roughed up while in captivity beaten.

name: 2005 Iraq Lebanese-Cypriot hostage
description:
A group calling itself "The Group for the Promotion of Virtue and Prevention of Vice" posted a video on the Internet on September 11 showing a man who identified himself as Garo Jikerjian, threatened by a gun. 


Lebanese-Cypriot, Garo Jikerjian worked in Iraq since August 2003 for Getco Trading, an importer of food and liquor for US-led coalition forces and the Iraqi army. He's been the first known Cypriot taken hostage in Iraq. He's been abducted in Bagdad. His father asked for his release in a video on December 9th. 


The group asked Getco Trading to end it's activities in Iraq, the company then closed it's Iraqi offices, according to the father of the hostage. The group initially demanded 20,000 dollars for Jikerjian's release, but once Getco Trading paid the ransom it has been elevated to one million dollars. 


Garo Jikerjian has been released on New Year's Eve, the family said a ransom of 200.000 dollars had ultimately been paid.

name: 2005 Iraq Florence Aubenas
description:
French journalist Florence Aubenas, preparing a report for daily newspaper Liberation on refugees from Fallujah, was taken hostage on January 2005 by four armed men in Baghdad's Jadida University along with her guide, Hussein Hanoun al-Saadi.

In a video tape given to news agency Reuters and broadcast on March 1,5 200 by Sky-Italia Aubenas spoke briefly in English, stating that her health was deteriorating. She was released on June 5, 2005.

name: 2004 Iraq Polish women
description:
Teresa Borcz-Khalifa was taken hostage on October 28 2004 in Iraq by a group calling itself "Abou Bakr Siddik Al-Salafia". Fifty-four years old, she had lived in Iraq for thirty years and was married to an Iraqi man.

The kidnapping was first claimed in a video made by the armed group and broadcast on cable channel Al Jazeera. The group asked Poland to pull its troops out from Iraq. The Polish government refused. In a second video, the hostage repeated the group's demand, and further demanded the release of Iraqi women held in US prisons. Borcz-Khalifa was released on November 20, 2004 and gave a press conference in Warsaw later the same day.

name: 2004 Iraq Polish hostages
description: Two Polish civilians employed by construction company Jedynka Wroclawskain Iraq were abducted on June 1, 2004 by a group of men in the offices of the telecommunication company Opto, along with three bodyguards and two Iraqi employees. One of them, Radoslaw Kadri, managed to escape. The other, JerzyKos, was freed on June 8, 2004 (along with three Italian hostages) south of Bagdad by a joint special forces operation. No ransom has been given.

name: 2004 Iraq Nasiriyah Gary Teeley
description: Briton Gary Teeley, 37, was kidnapped in the southern Iraqi city of Nasiriyah on April 5, 2004 while working outside an American base as a laundry contractor. He was held for six days. He was freed by the Italian special forces, during a raid on the offices of the Shia rebel leader Moqtada al Sadr. After his release, he claimed to have been 'mentally tortured'.

name: 2009-2013 Denis Allex, Somalia
description: On July 14th, 2009, Denis Allex is kidnapped in Mogadishu, the capital of Somalia, by a group of shebabs. They want to punish the "anti-islamic" politic of France. Spy of the DGSE, Denis Allex is officially in Somalia to train the local police, battling against numerous Islamist groups. Denis Allex was kidnapped with another agent, Marc Aubrière, who succeeded in escaping. Held by shebabs, the place of detention of Denis Allex is often changed. French intelligence service try to locate the hostage. On October 4th, 2012, Denis Allex's message is broadcast by shebabs. The agent seems tired and asks to president François Hollande to release him. In 2012, the French services succeed in locating Denis Allex. He is held in a village of the South of Somalia, Bulomarer. An operation rose to release him. French commando squads are sent to deliver him at night from 11 till 12 January 2013. But commando squads are spotted and a shooting bursts. 17 Islamists and two French soldiers are killed. According to the French State, the hostage Denis Allex is executed during this attack by his kidnappers. According to shebabs, the hostage was executed only on January 16th in answer to the French attack. The captivity of Denis Allex lasted more than three years, the longest for a French hostage after that of Ingrid Betencourt, which stayed about six years in the hands of the RAFC.

name: 2010 Niger Michel Germaneau
description: Deprived on April 19th, 2010 of the North of Niger by AQIM, Michel Germaneau was executed by the terrorist organization on July 24th, 2010. Suffering from a heart disease, the hostage was without medicine for several weeks. On July 11th, 2010, AQIM sends an ultimatum in France: if members of the organization detained in countries of Sahel are not released before July 28th, Michel Germaneau will be executed. Without news from her hostage, France, supported by units of the Mauritanian army, leads on July 22nd a raid against a camp of AQIM in the North of Mali susceptible to be the place of detention of Michel Germaneau. Seven Islamists are killed but the hostage is not in this camp. In reprisal, the leader of AQIM, Abou Moussab Abdel Wadoud, announces in a recording spread July 25th to have executed the day before Michel Germaneau. AQIM assures that France did not want to negotiate, France that terrorists didn't want.

name: 2008 Nigeria Port Harcourt
description:
27 oil workers were kidnapped by militants in the Niger Delta area in September 2008. Most of the group were released soon afterwards but Britons Matthew Maguire and Robin Hughes remained hostages. They were held for 9 months.

Their kidnappers were militants from the Movement for the Emancipation of the Niger Delta (MEND). They demanded the release of their leader, Henry Okah, in exchange for the hostages. Henry Okah was held by the Nigerian government on arms trafficking.

Robin Hughes was released on April 19, 2009. Matthew Maguire was released on June 12, 2009. He was the last hostage freed.

name: 2011 Nigeria Birnin Kebbi kidnapping
description:
Briton Christopher McManus and Italian Franco Lamolinara were kidnapped on May 12 2011. They were working for the same construction company, in northern Nigeria. They were abducted by gunmen, in their apartments at Birnin Kebbi. 

A German colleague managed to escape, but a Nigerian engineer was shot and wounded. An other Italian, Eduardo Cavallieri, avoided capture and raised the alarm. 

The captors were nigerian islamists linked to Al-Quaeda. They called themselves "Al-Qaeda in the land beyond the Sahil". In videos posted online, Christopher McManus asked the british government "to meet the demands of al-Qaeda."

After months in captivity, the authorities found out that Christopher McManus and Franco Lamolinara were held in Sokoto. The British special forces failed to free them on March 8, 2012. The two hostages were killed by their kidnappers during the raid.

name: 2009 Seychelles Kidnapping of Paul and Rachel Chandler
description:
Paul, 59, and Rachel Chandler, 55, were kidnapped from their sailing boat in the archipelago of the Seychelles during the night, on October 23, 2009. They were sailing across the Indian Ocean from the Seychelles to Tanzania when they were taken. The boat was later found empty by Britain's Royal Navy. In january 2010, the British forces tried to free them but it failed. 

Their captors ,Somali pirates demanded a ransom of $7 million dollars. The British government refused to pay. The couple was released on November 14, 2010, after a £600,000 ransom was paid by a private person. Chandlers' relatives raised the money between them, and it was dropped from an plane.

name: 2013 Democratic Republic of Congo
description: A German and an Austrian tourists were briefly abducted on January 5th 2013 by the Democratic Forces for the Liberation of Rwanda (FDLR) in Rutshuru, Democratic Republic of Congo. They were rescued by United Nations soldiers of the Monusco operation, in the village of Kisheguru.

name: 2008 Somalia Bosasso
description:
Briton Colin Freeman, 39, was the Sunday Telegraph's chief foreign correspondent. He was kidnapped with the spanish freelance photographer José Cendron. They were working on piracy in the Gulf of Aden. 

They were betrayed and kidnapped by their bodyguards in Somalia, during they travelled from the port of Bossaso to the airport, on November 26, 2008. In fact, they were somali pirates. 

They were held in caves, in the mountains near Bosaso. They were treated well. They were released on January 4, 2009, after six weeks of captivity.

name: 2011 Somalia Dadaab
description: Two Spanish employees of Doctors without borders were taken hostage in Dadaab, a Kenyan refugee camp complex, on October 13th 2011 by three never identified armed men who went straight to Somalia. Montserrat Serra, 40, and Blanca Thiebaut, 30, were freed almost two years later in Somalia. When they were kidnapped, they were building a hostpital in Ifo, one of the Dadaab camps.

name: 2005 Irish hostage in Iraq
description: Irish correspondent of the Guardian, Rory Carroll was released the day after his kidnapping in Baladiat, eastern Bagdad. He was kidnapped by armed men after an interview  with a victim of former Iraqi president, Saddam Hussein.

name: 2003 Colombia plane shot down
description:
Marc Gonçalves, a dual citizen of the United States and Portugual, was taken hostage in Colombia in February 2003 with two other Americans, Thomas Howes et Keith Stansell. They were on an anti-drug mission when their plane was shot down near Caquéta, about 350 kilometers southwest of Bogota. 

All three were freed on July 2, 2008 by an army-led helicopter rescue mission. French national Ingrid Betancourt was freed in the same operation, along with 11 Colombian officers.

name: 2000 Angola Cabinda hostages
description:
Three Portuguese expatriate workers were taken hostage by the Liberation Front for the Cabinda Enclave (FLEC) on May 24, 2000. Marco Santos and Manuel da Mota Nunes were released on June 25, 2001, after more than a year in captivity in Cabinda, an enclave of Angolan territory to the north of the Congo River. 

The release of the two captives followed diplomatic interventions by the governments of Gabon and The Republic of Congo.

The third hostage captured with them was released on April 3 in what the guerrillas called a “gesture of good will”. The rebels were seeking independence for Cabinda, a province which produces more than half of Angola's oil wealth.

Because Cabinda was administered separately from the rest of Angola in Portuguese colonial times it should have formed a separate state, according to the rebels, who tried to put pressure on Portugal, since they do not recognize Angolan authority over the disputed territory.

The rebels have their own internal divisions. The FLEC movement, originally known as the Liberation Front for the Cabinda Enclave, splited into three factions.

Five other Portuguese from Mota & Company construction company, who were captured by a rival separatist Cabinda movement, were freed on May 23, 2001 after 74 days of captivity in the Angolan jungle. All the hostages said they had been treated well by their captors.

name: 2005 Iraq Romanian journalists
description:
Romanian Prima TV journalists Marie Jeanne Ion and Sorin Miscoci were taken hostage with Eduard Ohanesian, correspondent Romania Libera, in Iraq on March 28, 2005 in Bagdad. Mohammad Munaf, their American-Iraqi fixer, was also abducted.

In April, their kidnappers, a group calling itself the Muadh Ibn Jabal Brigade, presented Bucharest an ultimatum to withdraw its 860 troops from Iraq but the ultimatum expired with no news on the fate of the hostages.

They were freed on May 22, 2005 in good health. No information was given about the terms of their release.

name: 2005 Iraq Christian Peacemaker
description:
Briton Norman Kember, American Tom Fox and Canadians James Loney and Harmeet Singh Sooden, four human rights workers of Christian Peacemaker Teams (CPT) were kidnapped in Iraq on November 26, 2005 by the Swords of Righteousness Brigade. This group demanded for the release of all Iraqi prisoners incarcerated in iraqi or american prisons. 

On March 10, the body of Tom Fox was found in Baghdad. The remaining three hostages were freed in a military operation on March 23, 2006.

name: 2014 Libya David Bolam
description:
Briton David Bolam, 63, was working in an international school when he was kidnapped, on May 19, 014, in the streets of Benghazi, in Libya. His kidnapping wasn't reported at the request of the Foreign Office and his family.

In a video posted online on August 28, David Bolam asked to British Prime Minister, David Cameron to secure his release. He was released at the beginning of October 2014. The kidnappers asked for a ransom. It had been paid but its amount is unknown.

name: 2008 Somalia Buale Kidnapping
description:
The British environmentalist Murray Watson and his Kenyan colleague Patrick Amukhuma, were working for a company under contract with the UN, during the civilian Somali war. They were doing research. 

They were kidnapped on April 1, 2008,  by unknown gunmen while they were conducting a survey near the city of Buale, in southern Somalia. They have totally disappeared since. Murray Watson and Patrick Amukhuma are presumed dead.

name: 2013 Atme Kidnapping
description:
David Haines, from Perth, Scotland, was an engineer. In 1999, he decided to turn to work in humanitarian. He helped victims of several conflicts (Yugoslavia, Africa, Middle East). In 2012, he worked as a security worker in South Sudan.

He was kidnapped in March 2013, near the Atmeh refugee camp, at the Turkish border. The camp was near the Syrian province of Idlib. He was seized by the jihadist group Islamic State. He was abducted with an Italian aid worker named Federico Motka. Federico Motka said David Haines had been tortured during his captivity. 

On 13 September 2014, the Islamic State sent a video "A Message to the Allies of America". It showed Haines beheaded by Jihadi John, a British fighter of the Islamic State.  

Federico Motka was freed in May 2014 after the Italian government paid a ransom of £5 million.

name: 2013 Syria Alan Henning
description:
Alan Henning, 47, was a British taxi driver. He joined an aid convoy and was taken hostage by militants of the Islamic State, on December 26, 2013, after crossing the border between Turkey and Syria. 

Alan Henning was executed on October 3, 2014 in retaliation for UK strikes against the jihadist group in Iraq. In a video posted online, he was beheaded by Jihadi John, an IS british fighter.

name: 2005 Iraq Spanish Businessman
description: An unidentified Spanish businessman of Iraqi origin was kidnapped in Iraq on March 6 while visiting family.  The man, who headed a real estate agency and a translation company in Spain, was freed on March 17 after his family paid a ransom to the kidnappers. The amount of the ransom was not disclosed.  The Spanish government is thought to have assisted in the negotiations.

name: 2003 Colombia Trekking group taken hostage
description:
Eight young tourists trekking to the 2,500-year-old ruins of Colombia's Lost City were abducted by rebels of the leftist National Liberation Army (ELN) on September 12, 2003.  Briton Matthew Scott, 19, escaped two days later and found his way to safety.  Two others – Spaniard Asier Huegun and German Reinhilt Weigel – were released on November 24, 2003. 

The remaining five -- Israelis Beni Daniel, Ortaz Ohayon, Ido Guy and Erez Altawil, along with Briton Mark Henderson – were released to mediators on December 22.

Dozens of rebel gunmen supervised the release, which followed months of negotiations facilitated by the Roman Catholic Church. The rebels said they kidnapped the men to publicize the persecution of Indian villagers by rightwing paramilitaries, and not for a ransom.

name: 2000 Georgia Spanish hostages
description:
Francisco Rodriguez and Luis Tremino, Spanish businessmen, were kidnapped from the Georgian capital Tbilisi on November 30, 2000 by unknown assailants.

They were held hostage for over a year in Georgia and freed on December 8th 2001, shortly after the release of Japanese reporter Kosuke Tsuneoka, 33, who had been kidnapped in Georgia's Chechen-populated Pankisi gorge.

The families of Rodriquez and Tremino gathered 300,000 euros (267,000 dollars) of ransom money in September 2001, but the kidnappers then demanded twice as much. The families appealed for individual donations.
After their release, Termino said: "They kept us in different places, often in a basement. They took us from place to place, and the food was bad." Rodriquez said: they did not understand the language their abductors spoke, "but sometimes one could hear Russian words."

Some 10,000 Chechens live in the Pankisi gorge. They include groups of independent fighters taking refuge on the Georgian side of the border with Chechnya, along with several thousand refugees.

name: 2008 Mali Tunisia Austrian Hostages
description:
Wolfgang Ebner, 51, and Andrea Kloiber, 44, are two Austrians taken hostage on February 22nd 2008 in Tunisia. They were freed in Mali by the north African branch of Al-Qaeda after more than eight months in captivity. 


The Austrian desert hiking enthusiasts disappeared in southern Tunisia in February as they were driving in their Austrian-registered four-wheel-drive vehicle. A few weeks later, Al-Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb claimed responsibility for their kidnapping. 


An internet statement posted in April in the name of Al-Qaeda demanded the release of two Islamists detained in Austria and the withdrawal of Austrian troops from Afghanistan in return for the lives of two Austrian hostages.


Among the prisoners the kidnappers want released is Amar Saifi, known as El Para, or The Paratrooper, a leading figure in the Algeria-based Salafist Group for Preaching and Combat (GSPC), which in 2006 allied itself to Al-Qaeda.


The hostages were moved to northern Mali -- a region that borders Algeria -- where the kidnappers initially demanded the release of a number of Islamic extremists imprisoned in Algeria and Tunisia.


The kidnappers initially set a March 16 deadline which they extended to March 23 and finally to April 6. They have threatened to kill the hostages if any attempt is made to free them by force.


Circumstances surrounding their release remain unclear. A source in the Malian security forces said simply that Ebner and Kloiber were released "1,000 kilometers to the north of the Kidal - Timbuktu", in a region which borders Mauritania and Algeria.


While Vienna denies any ransom was paid, sources close to the negotiations say money did change hands to secure a release. However, the Malian president stressed Saturday his country had not received any money or made any financial transaction in order to get the hostages freed.


The Austrian daily Kurier reported that the kidnappers -- from an Algerian-based outfit calling itself the Al-Qaeda Organisation in the Islamic Maghreb -- were demanding a ransom of five million euros (7.9 million dollars).


"The conditions of detention were harsh, it was not at all easy, but we were treated normally," Ebner said,<span> after 252 days in captivity.

name: 2006 Iraq Austrian Hostage
description:
Austrian Bert Nussbaumer, a 25-years-old security agent who worked in southern Iraq was taken hostage in november 2006 with four American coworkers. The group was kidnapped in Sawan, near Bassorah city. 


All five hostages appeared in a video published in January 2007 by National Islamic Resistance in Irak (Al-Furqan). The armed group claimed the kidapping credit and asked for the liberation of all prisoners made by American and Brittish armies in Iraq. However, the perpetrators never talked directly to Vienna. 



In late March 2008, The body of Bert Nussbaumer was found and identified. His American coworkers were also found dead. Paul Christopher Johnson-Reuben, Joshua Mark Munns, and John Roy Young also worked for Crescent Security in Iraq. They were escorting a Kowetian Red Cross convoy when they were kidnapped by men dressed like Iraqi policemen in Sawan, near Bassorah city, southern Iraq. 




The body of the fifth hostage wasn't found.

name: 2010 Mali AQIM Kidnapping
description:
The hostages, Albert Vilalta, 35, and Roque Pascual, 50, returned home to Spain early on August 24th 2010, after being held captive for nine months in Mali by Al-Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb (AQIM), the north African offshoot of Osama's bin Laden's terror group.

The mastermind behind the kidnapping of two Spanish aid workers was present in the Malian desert when they were released.

Omar Sid'Ahmed Ould Hamma, known as "Omar the Sahrawi", was sentenced to 12 years in prison in Mauritania for the kidnapping, but extradited to Mali and then freed just jours before the two Spanish hostages were released.

Hamma, a mercenary who was acting for AQIM, was freed in exchange for release of the aid workers, and even drove them to the handover point in the Malian desert, the newspaper El Pais said.

Spanish newspapers said Spain also paid between 7.0 and 8.0 million euros in exchange for Vilalta and Pascual.

El Mundo newspaper said the Madrid government paid out 6.8 million euros to secure the release of the two men and a third aid worker, Alicia Gamez, who was kidnapped at the same time and freed in March.

Al-Qaeda's branch said its demands were met. The statement from Al-Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb (AQIM) also said the release was a "lesson for the French secret service to take into consideration in the future", referring to a failed Mauritanian-French raid in Mali on July 22 that aimed to rescue French hostage Michel Germaneau and in which seven AQIM members were killed.

name: 2011 Algeria Tindouf
description:
Enrico Gonyalons, a Spanish Aid worker, was abducted in Tindouf, Algeria in October 2011 with two women colleagues (a Spanish national and an Italian national) by the Islamist group known as the Movement for Oneness and Jihad in West Africa (MUJAO). The three captives were working in refugee camps.

MUJAO, demanded the release of two Sahrawis arrested by Mauritania for their role in the kidnapping, as well as 30 million euros ($40 million), they also threatened to kill one of the Spanish hostages.

After almost 9 months in captivity, the Spanish hostages as Ainhoa Fernandez de Rincon and Enric Gonyalons, and the Italian as Rossella Urru were freed. MUJAO declared they received a ransom of 15 million euros and the liberation of a mujahidin. 

7 Algerians diplomats were also held in captivity with the european hostages. They were seized on April 5 in Gao, northern Mali, as several armed groups descended on the region following a coup in the capital Bamako.

name: 2013 Syria Spanish hostages
description:
Three Spanish journalists were taken hostage in Syria by an Al-Qaeda-linked group last year and freed on March 30th 2014.

El Mundo Middle East correspondent Javier Espinosacalled the paper's newsroom and said they had been released and handed over tothe Turkish military.

Espinosa and fellow hostage freelance photographerRicardo García Vilanova were kidnapped, along with a third Spanish journalist,in September 2013 at a "checkpoint" in Syria's border frontier withTurkey. All three had been attempting to leave the country.

There was no immediate word on the health of the twojournalists, whether any demands were made by their kidnappers or any ransompaid.

Their captors were earlier identified as members ofthe Islamic State of Iraq and the Levant, a jihadist faction in Syria withroots in Al-Qaeda's Iraqi affiliate.

Thethird kidnapped journalist, Marc Marginedas, a correspondent for Catalan dailyEl Periodico, was freed earlier in March, the 2nd.

name: 2008 Democratic Republic of Congo Belgian hostage
description:
Belgian journalist Thomas Scheen was taken hostage in Democratic Republic of Congo in 2008. He was working for the german newspaper Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung (FAZ) when he was kidnapped for three days by a Mai Mai tribal militia, in the area of Rutshuru. 

He was kidnapped along with his two Congolese colleagues. The militia wanted the retreat of National Congress for the Defence of the People troops from Rutshuru.

name: 2013 Belgian and Italian hostages in Syria
description:
As a Belgian teacher and a war journalist, Pierre Piccinin was doing his seventh trip to Syria since the beginning of the revolution when he was taken hostage in april 2013. He was abducted once before by rebels in may 2012.


In september 2013, he was liberated along with Italian journalist Domenico Quirico. During their five months detention, both men endured "physical violence".


Both men entered Syria through Lebanon on April 6th. Two months later, they were arrested in Qousseir by the FSL and handed to Abu Ammar's Katiba.


They tried to escape once, taking advantage from prayer time and grabbing kalachnikovs. They run for two days before they were captured back.

name: 2010 Cameroon Vespucci Belgian ship
description:
Armed men in the Cameroon port city of Douala abducted two sailors, the boat's Belgian owners said.

"The two men were taken hostage by armed men" in port overnight on Sunday, said Helen Schillinck, a spokeswoman for owners Jan De Nul.

One was Filipino and the other Croatian, she said. The dredger, the Vespucci, was Luxembourg-flagged.

The company was unable to provide any further details.

name: 2008 Guatemala Belgian hostages
description:
Four Belgian tourists, their Guatemalan guide and a boat operator were abducted on March 14, 2008, by Encuentro campesino, a group of Guatemalan farmers, near the Dulce river, 250 kilometers north-east from capital city of Guatemala. 

Gabriel Van Huysse, 64, Marie Paul Duboise, 62, Eric Stofferis, 62, and Jenny Belaen, 59, were released "after negociations" the next day, said François Delhaye, the spokesperson of Belgian Foreign Affairs ministry. 

The perpetrator organization asked for a trade between the four hostages and one of its leaders.

name: 2013 Yemen
description:
Judith Spiegel, a freelance journalist, and her husband Boudewijn Berendsen were taken from a house in Sanaa on 8 June 2013. They were both teaching in the University of Sanaa. 

They were released on 10 December 2013 close to the Dutch embassy.

In mid-July, Ms Spiegel made an impassioned plea for help in a video posted online.

She urged the Dutch authorities to do anything to secure their release and warned that if no solution was found within 10 days, she and Mr Berendsen might be executed by their "armed" captors.

name: 2009 Yemen Dutch couple
description:
A Dutch couple, Jan Hoogendoorn and his wife Heleen Janszen were taken hostage on March 31, 2009 in Yemen near Sanaa. Jan Hoogendoorn was working at a water project in the southern city of Taiz.Heleen Janszen said five men with Kalashnikov rifles surrounded their car while the couple was driving in the capital, Sanaa. 

They were released on April 14, 2009.

name: 2009 Nigeria Lithuanian sailors
description:
The crew members of the Lithuanian-flagged ship Saturnas - the captain, Sergejus Triskinas, together with four other Lithuanian sailors - were kidnapped in Nigeria on August 3rd, 2009. 

They were released on August 14th, 2009. 

According to the Limarko Shipping Company, owner of the boat, no ransom was paid. 

The ship had a total crew of 14, all of them Lithuanian citizens.

The attackers did not seize the vessel itself but left in a high-speed boat with the hostages.

name: 2011 Somalia Danish family
description:
Jan Quist Johansen, his wife, Birgit Marie, and their three teenage children, Rune, Hjalte and Naja, were captured along with two Danish crew members on February 24, 2011, when their 13 metre (47ft) yacht was seized by pirates in the Indian Ocean. They were on a round-the-world journey when they approached pirate-infested waters off the Horn of Africa, Somalia. 

They were released 6 months later on September 7, 2011. 

Danish authorities declined to comment further on the circumstances of the release, and would not say whether a ransom had been paid.

name: 2001 Colombia hostage
description:
46-year-old Erik Kjaersgaard Eriksen was kidnapped on March 17 or 18, 2001. He had been working on a European Union development project in a slum area near Bogota, capital of Colombia. He was released, unharmed, little more than a month later on April 23.

Danish media reported that Eriksen's girlfriend had been released after being initially held along with him.

It was presumed that  the far-left Colombian rebel group, the National Liberation Front (ELN), was behind the abduction.

name: 2011 Pakistan
description:
Olivier David Och, 31, and Daniela Widmer, 28, were taken hostage while travelling by camper van in the country’s volatile south-west. They were driving from India to Switzerland when they were snatched at gunpoint in Baluchistan, scene of a long-running insurgency and an area known for kidnappings. 

They presented themselves at a military checkpoint in North Waziristan, a Taliban and al-Qaeda stronghold, amid conflicting accounts about whether they escaped or were released in exchange for a ransom. 

Last week, a video released by the Taliban showed another captive, Ajmal Khan, vice-chancellor of a university in Peshawar, claiming the Swiss hostages were about to be released in return for 100 prisoners and a substantial payment.

name: 2012 Mali Swiss hostage
description: Béatrice Stockly, a Swiss national in her forties, has been abducted by a group of armed men on April 15, 2012, north of Mali. Following a shooting between two groups in Timbuktu, she has then been taken by Ansar Dine, who finally released the hostage. Béatrice Stockly has been handed over to Swiss diplomats on April 24, 2012. An Ansar Dine local chief claimed that no ransom had asked nor given for the release.

name: 2001 Istanbul Swissôtel
description:
More than 600 staff and guests -- notably several Britons, 6 Austrians, 54 Americans and 15 Swiss (including a Swissair flight crew of 9) -- were seized when armed men stormed a five-star hotel in Istanbul at around 11 p.m. on Sunday, April 22, firing as they came through its main entrance. Up to 100 persons were held hostage overnight before being freed 12 hours later.Up to 100 persons were held hostage overnight before being freed 12 hours later.

The hostage-takers identified themselves as Chechen rebels and told CNN by phone that they were demanding the United States use its influence to denounce Russia for its part in the war in Chechnya.

The gunmen said they had staged the raid in order to draw attention to the plight of their ethnic bretheren in Chechyna and demanded talks with Sadettin Tantan, Turkey's interior minister. The meeting took place at 10.30 a.m. and the rebels surrendered half an hour later, with 13 suspects led away.

During their captivity, many of the hostages were kept in a fifth floor conference room and forced to listen to Chechen national songs.

The standoff involved about 20 gunmen. Police said they had encountered no resistance there were no reports of injuries or deaths.

It was the first time a large group of Westerners had been caught up in the Caucasian conflict.

name: 2005 Yemen
description:
A couple from Switzerland, Bruno and Katerina Baer were kidnapped in Yemen, in the province of Maareb - 170 kilometers east of Sanaa - on 21st November 2005. 

They were freed one day later on 22nd November 2005. 

The perpetrator, Hassan al-Demn asked for the liberation of his brother Saleh. His brother was arrested at the end of October for a car robbery.

name: 2009 Niger Tuarag tribe festival
description:
Four persons were kidnapped on January 22, 2009 in Niger near the frontier with Mali. They were at a Tuarag tribe festival. Two tourists from Switzerland, Gabriella Burco and her husband Werner Greiner, and two other tourists, Briton Edwen Dyer and German Marianne Petzold. They were held hostage in Mali by al-Qaeda in the Islamic Magreb (AQIM). The terrorist group demanded the release of their imprisoned comrade, Abu Qatada.

Gabriella Burco and Marianne Petzold were freed on April 22, 2009. Edwin Dyer was killed on May 31, 2009. Werner Greiner was freed on July 12, 2009.

name: 2008 Colombia hostages
description:
19 tourists were taking a cruise on the Atrato river, in the Colombian departement of Choco, when the FARC guerillas kidnapped them on January 14th, 2008. 

Most of them were freed. Alf Onshus Nino, a Norwegian-Columbian professor of the University of Bogota was one of the last hostage freed on the 3rd of July of 2008.

name: 2000 Russia hostage
description:
A 43-year old Norwegian businessman was kidnapped in Moscow by two men wearing police uniforms and carrying automatic rifles. He was held hostage for four days in a forest about 50 kilometers north of Moscow. The perpetrators were presumed to be part of a criminal organization from the Republic of Dagestan. They asked for a $US 200,000 ransom. 

The hostage's identity was held secret. He was liberated in a special operation.

name: 2011 AQIM kidnapping
description:
On 25 November 2011, Swedish hostage Johan Gustafsson, Dutch hostage Sjaak Rijke, and South African hostage Stephen Malcolm were kidnapped from a hostel in Timbuktu in an attack that left a German man dead. 

The kidnappings were claimed by Al-Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb (AQIM), which released two photos to back up their claim.

The last time he was seen alive was on 21 August 2012. The Qatari television channel Al-Jazeera broadcasted a video that identified the three hostages. In the video, they asked their native countries to negotiate with AQIM.

French hostage Serge Lazarevic was held in captivity with them.

name: 2013 Algeria In Amenas Hostage Crisis
description:
The In Amenas hostage crisis started on January 16, 2013. A group of terrorists, linked to Al-Qaeda and led by Mokhtar Belmokhtar, attacked the Tigantourine gas facility near In Amenas, Algeria. 

32 Islamist terrorists came from Libya and northern Mali, and attacked a bus transporting employees. A guard succeeded in activating an alarm. He was killed by the terrorists immediately afterward. A Briton was also killed and at least seven others were injured during theis first assault.

After, during a few hours, terrorists searched for foreigners workers. They killed and hit several of them. A few ones were forced to wear explosive on their chest or around their neck.  A lot of foreigners succeeded to survive in hiding. 

The terrorists demanded the end to French military operations in northern Mali. They also demanded to return safely to Northern Mali and ransom for the hostages.

Algerian security forces surrounded the site. The next day, the terrorists, divided in two groups, decided to reunite. They were attacked by the Algerian military forces. A few hostages escaped. On January 18, the terrorists exploded a bomb murdering a few more hostages.

After four days, the Algerian special forces attacked them in order to free the hostages. 11 militants and 7 hostages were killed in this final assault. 16 foreign hostages were freed. At the end of the crisis, 29 of the attackers were killed and 3 captured alive. 

According to the American authorities, 132 foreign nationals were taken hostage. In all, more than 800 people were taken hostage. At least 39 foreign hostages were killed with an Algerian security guard. A total of 685 Algerian workers and 107 foreigners were freed.

name: 2007 Colombia Larsson
description:
Erik Roland Larsson, 69, was abducted May 17, 2007, by the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) from his house in northern Colombia. 

He was released near the city of Monteria, some 500 kilometers (310 miles) northeast of Bogota.

The FARC demanded $5 millions for his release. Erik Roland Larsson was partly paralyzed from a suspected stroke. It was not known whether he was released for health reasons or because money had been paid.

His Colombian companion, Diana Pena <span>was kidnapped with him but escaped during a battle between security forces and guerrillas soon afterwards.

name: 2005 Iraq Minas Ibrahim al-Yussufi Kidnapping
description:
Minas Ibrahim al-Yusufi, leader of Iraq's Christian Democrats, was kidnapped in Iraq by the Iraqi Vengeance Battalion (aka the Martyr al-Isawi Brigade) on January 27, 2005 while traveling to the northwestern city of Mosul.

Yusufi, who holds Swedish citizenship, had returned to Iraq in 2003 after living in Sweden for twenty years to partake in politics after the fall of Iraqi leader Saddam Hussein. During his detention, he contacted his family in Sweden by mobile telephone. In a videotape broadcast on February 17, he was shown with an assault rifle pointed at his head. In a subsequent videotape, made public, he said he expected to be killed. 

Yusufi’s relatives in Sweden struggled to raise 400,000 dollars for the ransom demanded by his kidnappers, who had threatened to behead him. Initially they had asked for four million dollars. Yusufi was released on March 17, 2005. It is not known whether a ransom was paid.

name: 2001 eastern Democratic Republic of Congo
description:
Twenty-four Thais, a Kenyan and Bjoern Rugsten, a Swedish truck supplier for a foreign logging company, were kidnapped by the Mai Mai Resistance Forces near the Ugandan border on May 16 at Mangina, in the Butembo region of the Democratic Republic of Congor.

The Mai Mai condemn the presence in the DRC of Rwandan and Ugandan troops aligned with anti-Kinshasha rebels. They also describe the the extraction of regions natural resources by foreign companies as the "plundering of our riches".

Rugsten was released on June 30, 2001. The last 18 hostages were released on July 29, 2001. The Mai Mai said the release took place following mediation by DRC opposition politician Francois Lumumba. At the time, the Mai-Mai said their condition for the release of the remaining hostages was "the unconditional departure of all foreign troops, the Ugandans, the Rwandans and the Burundians" from eastern DRC.

name: 2000 Somalia Mogadishu kidnapping
description:
The kidnapping occurred on March 27, 2000 during an attack on the Mogadishu offices of the humanitarian organisation Médecins Sans Frontières (MSF). Twelve Somali civilians died in the attack, which was led by Somali warlord Musa Sudi Yalahow, leader of the Somali Reconciliation and Restoration Council (SRRC). 

The gunmen kidnapped six United Nations staff, three foreign aid workers and one Somalian. The British hostages Bill Condie and Roger Carter were freed on April 4, 2000.

name: [2013] Palawan Island hostage taking
description:
Heinrike Dielen, 55, and Stefan Okonek, 74, were sailing next from the Palawan Island when "people wearing police uniforms" came to meet them. They said they had to proceed to a simple control of their sailing ship. Then, they began the assault and they have been brought to Jolo Island. 

Abu Sayyaf, that swore allegiance to ISIS after firstly being helped by Al-Qaeda, claimed for a ransom of $4,38 millions and the stop of occidental airstrikes against djihadists in Iraq and Syria. 

On October 17th 2014 the two hostages were liberated and came back to Germany. Abu Sayyaf said they obtained the ransom they claimed whereas the German government affirmed they did not pay any ransom.

name: 2012 NLA kidnapping
description:
Uwe Breueur, 69, and Gunther Otto Breueur, 73, are two German brothers. They were in Latin America for a long journey. They had been captured on 3rd November 2012 in Catatumbo, Colombia, by gunmen from the National Liberation Army (NLA). The armed group decided to kidnap them because they considered as spies — they were not in capacity of saying the reasons of their trip in Colombia. For a long time, the NLA exhorted German government for identity proofs. 

They had been captured for four months. Finally, they had been freed on March, 8th 2013.

name: 2012 Kidnapping in Nigeria
description:
Edgar Fritz Raupach, a German engineer, abducted in January 2012 by gunmen in northern Nigeria in the city of Kano.

Al-Qaeda in the Islamic Maghreb (AQIM) members claimed the liberation of Oum Seiv Al-Islam-Al-Ansariya, a Muslim woman detained in Germany. 

After few negotiations, Edgar Fritz Raupach was killed on May, 31 2012 during a failed rescue bid.

name: 2009 Yemen attack
description:
A group of nine European people was captured in the Sa'dah region in Yemen, the headquarter of the Shiite rebellion. They were employed by a medical NGO. The Europeans had been captured by a group whose leader is Abdul-Malik al-Houthi, an islamist group of brothers. 

A few hours after this kidnapping, three bodies had been found dead (two German girls and one North-Korean girl). 

The captors of the Briton and the five-member family claimed a two-million dollars ransom for their liberation, according to the Spiegel. 

After a fews days, rebels said they had not captured the hostages. 

In May 2010, Saudi forces succeeded in liberated Sabine and Johannes Hentschel's two little girls, Lydia, 3, and Anna, 5. The family remained held by armed group until their death, announced in 23 September 2014, after five years of captivity.

name: 2007 Iraq German hostages
description:
On 10th March, an islamist group named Kataeb Siham al-Haq diffused a video showing the two German-citizen praying for their liberation. The group asked the German government to "announce and begin the withdrawal of German troops in Afghanistan".

After several days of negotiations, a ten-day ultimatum had been accepted by the islamist group. 

On 11th July 2007, Hannelore Krause, 62, is freed. But her son, Sinan, is still in the hand of Kataeb Siham al-Haq. Today, we still do not have any information about his life.

name: 2006 Nigeria Delta
description:
Guido Schiffarth was an employee of the German group of oil services company Bilfinger Berger. He had been captured on 3 August, 2006.

Three days after this kidnapping, the raptors claimed they were the Niger Delta Movement People (NDMP), a unknown group at the time. They said the hostages would be liberated if government accepted to free of two leaders of NDMP, including Bayelsa Diepreye Alamieyaseigha and Mujahid Dokubo Asari — two men that would be judged for corruption and betrayal. In addition, this group longed for the autonomy or the independence of Niger Delta. 

Finally, Guido Schiffarth had been freed on 19 August, 2006.

name: 2006 German hostages in Iraq
description:
Two German engineers had been captured in Iraq on 24 January, 2006. The two. René Bräunlich, 32, and Thomas Nitzschke, 28, both from Leipzig, used to work in Baïji, 150 miles from the North of Baghdad. 

Their captors presented themselves as a Sunni group called "Saraya al-Moudjahidine: Katibat Ansar al-Tawhid wal-Sunna". They had diffused a video showing asking for their liberation. 

In a release, captors exhorted American government to free all Iraqis in jail and wanted German government to stop helping Washington in Baghdad. Captors firstly gave a 72-hour long ultimatum to Berlin. Then, they ask $12 millions for their liberation. Finally, they have been captured after four months of captivity. 

After the liberation, The Times said Germany paid a ransom of $5 millions — an information unconfirmed by the government.

name: 2005 Nigeria German workers
description: On June 15t, 2004, six employees of Bilfinger Berger Gas and Oil Services Ltd (BandB) - affiliated to the German group Julius Berger were abducted by Ijaw militants on the Niger Delta, south of Nigeria. The hostages include two German nationals and four Nigerian workers. They were released on June 18, no ransom has been given and no hostage has been hurt. The Ijaw militants were trying to pressure Shell and chose BandB because of the services they furnish to Oil companies.

name: 2003 Sahara hostage
description:
Thirty-two European trekkers were abducted in February and March 2003 in southern Algeria’s vast Sahara desert region by Islamic extremists, thought to be part of the Salafist Group for Preaching and Combat (GSPC), an Algerian radical group linked to al-Qaeda.  The hostages was later moved to a remote region of northern Mali.

Seventeen of the hostages were freed in a raid by Algerian special forces in May of the same year.  Fourteen others -- nine Germans, four Swiss and a Dutchman – were released after nearly six months on August 18.  One woman, 46-year-old German Michaela Spitzer, died while in captivity due to health complications, according to other hostages.

The German government, which led negotiations for the release of the second group, denied that Berlin paid a ransom. The German media, however, citing background sources, claimed 4.6 million euros (5.1 million dollars) was paid out, about a tenth of the original ransom asked for.

   A first group of 17 was freed in a raid by Algerian special forces in May, while one of the remaining hostages,46-year-old German mother of two Michaela Spitzer, died at the end of June.

name: 2002 Moscow theatre terrorist attack
description:
On October 23, 2002, some 50 Chechen rebels entered a Moscow theater and took more than 700 persons hostage. They demanded the withdrawal of Russian forces from Chechnya and an end to the so-called Second Chechen War. At the end of this hostage crisis, 170 persons were left dead (133 hostages and 40 terrorists). 

Two German citizens -- an 18-year-old student and a 43-year-old shop-keeper -- were among the hostages.  Both were eventually liberated.   

Britons Peter Sidica and Peter Low were also taken hostage. Both survived the attack.

Emilia Predova-Uzunov, a 43-years-old Austrian was among the hostages resuced by Russian forces, but later died in hospital from wounds sustained during the seige.

name: 2002 Sudan German Aid Workers
description:
Two Germans working for the humanitarian organization World Vision,
Ekkehard Forberg and Steffen Horstemeir, both 31, were kidnapped along with two African aid workers on July 29 in Waat, a town in south Sudan's Upper Nile region.

Both were released on August 4.  One of the African aid workers, Charles Kibe, 46, was killed by the rebel group responsible for the kidnapping, the Southern Sudan Liberation Movement, a dominantly Christian group fighting for independence against the Khartoum-based Islamist regime.
